Updated: November 15, 2016 @ 8:53 am Full Forecast News Sports Life Entertainment Dining Buy & Sell Close Matt Rourke Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton walks off the stage after speaking in New York, Wednesday, Nov. 9, 2016. Clinton conceded the presidency to Donald Trump in a phone call early Wednesday morning, a stunning end to a campaign that appeared poised right up until election day to make her the first woman elected U.S. president.(AP Photo/Matt Rourke) Mayor Paul Soglin: Hillary Clinton never tried to win over the working class MAYOR PAUL SOGLIN | Madison mayor Nov 11, 2016 Matt Rourke Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton walks off the stage after speaking in New York, Wednesday, Nov. 9, 2016. Clinton conceded the presidency to Donald Trump in a phone call early Wednesday morning, a stunning end to a campaign that appeared poised right up until election day to make her the first woman elected U.S. president.(AP Photo/Matt Rourke) The definitive article explaining Donald Trump’s success was published two weeks ago in the Oct. 31, 2016, issue of The New Yorker. "The Unconnected: The Democrats lost the white working class. The Republicans exploited them. Can Hillary Clinton win them back?" The obvious and short answer is obvious: No. The longer answer is: She never tried. Election night I received a continuous stream of text messages from relatives and friends from coast to coast asking me “What’s happening?” “Why?” and the most poignant from our oldest daughter, 32-year-old Rachael, “Do Americans really hate women that much?” (No sweetie, just Hillary.) For 35 years, the Republican Party spun a narrative that the loss of jobs, good jobs, was the fault of Democratic regulation and taxes crippling the captains of industry. This tale of fantasy economics long discredited by a myriad of Democrats and some conservatives was never conveyed to working Americans, with the exception for a short duration by Bernie Sanders, and to a lesser degree by Elizabeth Warren, Nancy Pelosi and others who never had the national forum of Hillary Clinton. Clinton’s effort to embrace working Americans was short fused and undermined by her own attacks on Donald Trump’s insensitivities and the baggage she accumulated over 20 years. That said, the first successful, though not intentional, effort to sabotage the Hillary Clinton presidency was orchestrated by Bill Clinton when he embraced the George H.W. Bush NAFTA treaty and steamrolled his own party. For 35 years, the Republican Party spun its narrative, fooling the American workers and never being held accountable for its destruction of the American middle class as Democrats cavorted with Wall Street, bankers, and international financiers. For 25 years, the Democratic Party led by the Clintons sucked up to Walmart and Wall Street while claiming to defend the American workers. The Waltons might or might not have voted for Hillary, but rest assured Walmart workers and Walmart shoppers voted for Donald Trump. So did Kmart shoppers. Recall those standard questionnaires with a range of 10 spots from "extremely agree" at one end to "extremely disagree" at the other end and "neutral" in the middle. Now fashion it with "I care about my friends and neighbors" at one end and "I’ve been screwed over one too many times" at the other end. Screwed-over working America did not care that the Republican Party was mostly responsible for their plight, they did not care that the states with failed job growth strategies — like Wisconsin and Kansas — were run by Republican governors who screwed the poor and gave tax breaks to their buddies. Screwed-over Kansans and Wisconsinites, like the rest of America, saw each political party offer up a populist. The carefully orchestrated Democratic Party nominating system was rigged, polite, and stacked — and they rejected their populist, Bernie Sanders. The Republican Party's process was chaotic, impolite, and offensive — and they chose the clear, strong, angry voice: their populist, Donald Trump. The voters chose strident voice, not party. The consequences for the Democratic Party are a disaster. A majority of America did not care who created the mess — they wanted an alternative, they wanted revenge. As the campaign for president came to a close, there were tell-tale signs of the wheels coming off the Clinton campaign bus. There were too many undecideds, who in the end broke against the incumbent, against the establishment. And all those angry white males. Some of them were white men, others were brown and black men, and some were women. But there were too many angry genetic white males and the Clinton campaign ignored them. Then there was the failed media campaign. Two of the cardinal rules of politics were violated by Hillary Clinton, both lessons I learned 40 years ago in my first term in office. First, never attack the voters. No matter what you think of your opponents, do not call their base of supporters indecent, shameless, or deplorable. Secondly, never utter any opinion or position in private that you are not willing to say in public. If that was true in the 1970s it is more true today when everyone in the room has their own recording device. Having failed two rules, the Clinton campaign barreled forward to follow the third rule as the campaign concluded: Always play to your strength. The theme of the campaign was to continue to appeal to equity and social justice, the empathy of the American people. Donald Trump was a never-ending wealth of material for those who cared about their friends and neighbors. There was the attack on the disabled, the Mexicans and Latinos, and especially his crude direction to tell whoever was listening to “Go fuck themselves.” Rest assured none of Donald Trump’s friends ever wrote a book entitled anything like “It Takes a Village.” Those angry white males, those undecideds, that basket of deplorables wanted to read, “How to Get Yours and Screw Everyone in Authority.” Like this story? Get our best of the week sent to your inbox Sign Up! I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site consitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy. If there is a surprise in all of this, it is that the Trump campaign did not double down and rerun the Hillary Clinton campaign's anti-Trump ads. In his New Yorker article, focusing on the divide between white working-class America and the rest of the nation, George Packer recounts: "When I asked her (Hillary Clinton) if this (educational elitism) had helped drive working-class Americans away from the Democratic Party, she hedged. 'I really don’t know the answer to that…'" How Clintonesque. She spent 20 years preparing to run for president. She took money from Wall Street while spinning them one story and her social justice colleagues another. She and Bill did amass a fortune and, when most politicians knew better, even set herself above the rest — not just the commoners but also the rest of the elites. There were the emails and then there were the foreign gifts to the Clinton Foundation while she was secretary of State. When she failed to answer Packer, once again she either lied or fudged. In either case, she was following in the tradition of every U.S. president over the past 35 years — fucking over working Americans. The difference is that whether it hubris, indifference, or arrogance, she did not have the filter to cover it up. Not when she answered Packer, not when she won the nomination, and not when she squared off against Donald Trump. It was obvious last spring that most Americans were mad as hell and there were two candidates who understood that. Bernie Sanders reflected and addressed it in a thoughtful, compassionate manner, not crying for blood, but demanding reasonable reforms. Donald Trump understood it and exploited and manipulated the long-suffering victims of both political parties. With Sanders out of the way, Hillary, who was too removed, too distant from the alienated, disenfranchised workers, sallied forth, offering platitudes and homilies but failing to give the people what they really wanted, the architects of the current economy. Trump never hesitated to sacrifice his bankers, his friends, and his investors. In meantime, none of us have a clue as to Trump’s real intentions on the economy. We know his stated positions on immigration and Supreme Court nominations but not much more. He may well create as much chaos for the Republican Party as he does for the Democrats, creating a very vulnerable GOP in 2018. The problem is Hillary Clinton smashed up the Democratic Party far worse than Lyndon Johnson and Hubert Humphrey could ever imagine. Paul Soglin is mayor of Madison. This column was first posted on his blog, "Waxing America."  Share your opinion on this topic by sending a letter to the editor to tctvoice@madison.com. Include your full name, hometown and phone number. Your name and town will be published. The phone number is for verification purposes only. Please keep your letter to 250 words or less. Target, Walmart, And Best Buy Announce Huge Black Friday Deals, Battlefield 1 And Titanfall 2 Over 40% Off Home News Chris May November 10th, 2016 - 10:08 AM Buy games related on this topic at | Amazon Tis the season to be jolly which means you can expect fa la la la lots of sales on some of the hottest releases over the coming months. So far three major US retailers, Target ,Walmart, and Best Buy have announced their Black Friday deals. If you’ve been holding back purchasing Battlefield 1 or Titanfall 2 then now is the time to pull the trigger. Best Buy, Walmart, and Target are selling the games at a serious discount.  You can get them at Target for $35 each and at Walmart for $27 each. This applies to the Xbox One and PS4 versions at Target and Walmart. Walmart will also be Titanfall 2‘s PC version at the same discount. Best Buy is selling Titanfall 2 for $35. Here’s a list of the myriad of games that are on sale and at which store. Walmart: Gears Of War 4 – $35 Call of Duty: Infinite Warfare Legacy Edition – $57 Battlefield 1 – $27 Titanfall 2 – $27 Rise of the Tomb Raider: 20th Anniversary Celebration – $35 Bioshock: The Collection – $35 Lego Dimensions Starter Pack – $39 Additional Lego Dimensions Packs – $14 Overwatch – $35 Deus Ex: Mankind Divided – $35 Destiny: The Collection – $35 Skyrim: Special Edition – $25 Target: Battlefield 1 – $35 Titanfall 2 – $35 Lego Dimensions Starter Pack – $39 Additional Lego Dimensions Packs – $10 Mario Maker (Wii U) – $35 No Man’s Sky – $35 Overwatch – $35 Super Smash Bros. (Wii U) – $35 Best Buy: Dark Souls 3 – $20 Rainbow Six: Siege – $20 Fallout 4 – $20 Recore – $20 Overwatch – $35 Titanfall 2 – $35 Bioshock: The Collection – $30 Mafia 3 – $30 Deus Ex: Mankind Divided – $30 Destiny: The Collection – $30 If you are in the market for a new console to play those games on you are in luck because all three retailers are selling either the PS4 Slim or Xbox One S or both at a discount. Target has an Xbox One S/Battlefield 1 and a Xbox One S/Minecraft bundle with a $40 gift card for $250. Walmart is advertising the same price minus the Minecraft bundle and the gift card. Polygon reports that Walmart will also be selling a 500 GB PS4 Slim bundle with a $30 gift card and three games (The Uncharted Collection, The Last Of Us: Remastered, and Ratchet & Clank) for $250. Best Buy will be offering the same Xbox One S/Minecraft bundle and PS4 Slim bundle minus the gift cards for $250. All of these sales kick off on Black Friday so plan accordingly, get their early, and for the love of god stay safe. They’re just video games after all. TechnoBuffalo Site Navigation Content All News Reviews Videos Galleries Products Giveaways Sections Menu Left Mobile Tablets Gaming Apps Accessories Computers Gadgets Internet Menu Right Business Cameras Cars Design Home & TV Lifestyle Software Science Series Ask The Buffalo Buffalo Gear Guess the Phone Rettinger’s Riffs Rumor Roundup The TechnoBuffalo Show TechnoBuffalo Plays More The Crew About Us News Tips In the News Work at TechnoBuffalo Advertise With Us Facebook Google+ Instagram Pinterest RSS Tumblr Twitter YouTube Scrolling Enable Endless Scrolling Disable Endless Scrolling Share Tweet +1 Submit Front Page /Gadgets/Deals/Gallery Gadgets Walmart Black Friday sale has crazy-good tech deals By Todd Haselton | November 11, 2016 Share Stay Connected with Us! Follow TechnoBuffalo Walmart recently revealed all of the items that will be available in stores come Black Friday. The weekly ad is chock full of tech, including plenty of discounted HDTVs, smartphones, accessories, streaming gadgets, home cameras and more. I took screenshots of the ad, which you can peruse at your will, but there are some standout deals that I spotted. If you buy a Galaxy S7 or iPhone 7 on AT&T or Verizon, for example, you’re eligible for a $250 Walmart gift card. You need to set an appointment ahead of time, however. Walmart’s Black Friday deals will save you big on tech For folks interested in creating a smart home, the Nest will be discounted from $249 to $199. The Nest Cam will cost $149, down from $299. For gamers, the Xbox One S Battlefield 1 bundle is priced at $249, down from $299. There are more than 65 games priced under $25, too, with many as low as $15 or $8. If you’re in need of a new laptop, Walmart has a variety of Windows 10 machines that are discounted down to as low as $99. Those super-cheap machines don’t always perform well, though, so keep that in mind before buying one. If you love movies, head to Walmart for those, too. More than 260 movies will cost just $3.96. Sure, most of us don’t use DVDs anymore, but if you buy a Disney movie, you can easily grab a digital copy for your smartphone or tablet. Boom, huge savings. And finally, TVs. There are tons of options, including a 4K 60-inch Samsung Smart TV priced at $648, which seems like a pretty good deal to me. Prices range from $98 for a 24-inch display to $798 for a 65-inch Samsung Smart TV, a $200 discount on the latter. Check out the full list in the gallery above, or hit the source to browse the full collection that also includes non-tech items. The sale kicks off at 6pm local time on November 24 in-stores. Good luck. Source Walmart Topics #Black Friday 2016 #Walmart Todd Haselton Todd Haselton has been writing professionally since 2006 during his undergraduate days at Lehigh University. He started out as an intern with MaximumPC Magazine and has since written for Ars… Read More Our Crew | About Us | Contact Us © 2016 TechnoBuffalo LLC. All Rights Reserved. Talk Business & Politics you're viewing Statewide change region Central Arkansas Northeast Arkansas Northwest Arkansas Fort Smith area Save Statewide Name Menu Microsites Finance Energy Startup Manufacturing Tourism Healthcare Close Business Politics Video / Podcasts Advertise Contact Us Community Member stories Create an account Submit a blog post Close Wal-Mart welcomes veterans to its Bentonville headquarters in honor of Veterans Day by Kim Souza. Published Nov 11th, 2016 4:57 pm ksouza@talkbusiness.net / @tbarkansas Wal-Mart Stores CEO Doug McMillon on Friday asked Hoyt Williams, a 93-year-old World War II veteran who works as a greeter in Trion, Ga., if he had any advice for the audience. “Just hang in there,” Williams answered. At the eleventh hour of the eleventh day of November, Wal-Mart Stores rolled out the red carpet for several World War II veterans who work or whose families work within the retailer’s vast ranks. The event was held at the retailer’s Bentonville headquarters. Williams served in the European and South Pacific Campaigns of WW II. After Potsdam, he was not ready to leave the military and return to civilian life so he was shipped to Seattle and then re-deployed to the Philippines until the war ended. Gary Profit, senior director of Wal-Mart’s military programs, said serving in both campaigns is rare, but then again so is someone who at 93 still wants to get more hours on the job. Williams has been a Walmart U.S. employee for the 23 years, a job he told Talk Business & Politics he sought after retiring from a 40-year run in the grocery business in his home town. “I told my wife when we left the grocery business and I was tired of mowing the lawn that it was time for me go back to work. I went down to my local Walmart and the assistant manager knew me. Her family used to buy groceries from me when she was a little girl. She said they could put me to work even though I was 70 years old and they did,” Williams said. He’s grateful the job which he works 4 days a week, but said he’d like to get mores if the store manager would given them. “Pay day is the best thing about the job,” he said. “I also like being with the people, retail is what I know,” Williams said. Wal-Mart Stores CEO Doug McMillon and Lois Bouton, who served as a “SPAR” with the U.S. Coast Guard between 1943-1945. SPARs comes from the Latin and English translations of the Coast Guard’s motto, Semper Paratus! Always Ready! He said over the past 23 years he’s had several jobs at his local Walmart store working in various departments including sporting goods, hardware, electronics and even fabric before transitioning to greeter nearly 4 years ago. Wal-Mart has made clear its commitments to hire veterans of all ages. In 2013 Walmart U.S. committed to hiring 100,000 veterans in five years, but McMillon said the retailer accomplished that goal in three years. The company reassessed the goal in 2013 to hire 250,000 by 2020, setting the bar higher. Since 2013, McMillon said the retailer has hired 153,000 veterans and 19,000 of them have been promoted. McMillon introduced Johnny Martin, who works in asset management for the Sam’s Club in Oklahoma City. Martin is in the U.S. Army reserves and has served three tours in Iraq – totaling more than 32 months. He has a master’s degree and still had trouble finding work after returning home in 2014. He said Target passed on him, saying he was “too professional” essentially over-qualified for the positions they had open. Martin said he kept a running total of his jobs applications – 152 – before he landed a job at Sam’s Club. “I took an overnight position and thought I would work on finding career employment in the day. But I quickly saw it was working out and was promoted to a department level supervisory role in a short time frame. I was encouraged to apply for the asset management position at the new Sam’s Club but I thought it would go to some with lots more experience. I had only 14 months with Sam’s Club at the time,” Martin said. Martin was called to deploy just after Thanksgiving for a short tour in the Ukraine. “I have found Walmart’s commitment to veterans is not just an empty HR promise,” he said. Other speakers at the Veterans Day event included James McDonough Jr.. director of the Institute for Veteran and Military Families. Together with more than $40 million in funding from the Walmart Foundation, IVMF has programs in North Carolina, New York and most recently San Antonio, Texas. The programs work to help veterans today returning from service transition back into the workforce, school or some other form of service. He said someone retiring or coming home from extended service is jobless and sometimes homeless. While there are many programs and employers to help there is not anyone to help make the connections in what is a very fragmented sector. Helping veterans navigate the services and employment landscape is what IVMS does. Rear Admiral Terence McKnight (retired) also spoke at the event about the service today in the 21st Century. He remembers well the call he got while serving in the Pentagon in 2009 to help try and save merchant Captain Richard Phillips who was under attack by Somali pirates in the Gulf of Aden. During 2007-2011, was in charge of operations to chase modern-day pirates that were a threat to commerce. “We have the greatest Navy in the world but we were not trained to chase pirates. I was the most scared guy out there. The Somali pirates do it out of desperation and annual income of just $350. Half of those pirates who go to sea don’t return. They have nothing to lose,” he said. Keeping the passage clear through the Gulf of Aden is crucial to commerce as some 25,000 ships pass through there annually. At the time of the pirate crusades he said there was not enough Coast Guard and Navy ships policing the region. He said the first and second groups his team captured, were released because the U.S. did not have a plan in place on how to handle those captured. He said those who had the misfortune to be captured by the Russians were not as fortunate. Walmart officials also encouraged the several hundred in attendance to support the “Green Light A Vet” marketing program the retailer introduced this time last year.  Profit said the idea of replacing an outdoor light bulb with a green bulb is hit, so much so that the retailer ran out of green light bulbs last year. Walmart said it sold 2 million green lights last year, and Profit said supplies are good because they have a better estimate on demand. Contests Deals Service Directory Print Display Ads Nifty Nickel FAQ   You are here Home » Business Nationwide discount chain...On its 25th anniversary,...     Posted November 11, 2016 - 2:39pmUpdated November 11, 2016 - 3:45pm Walmart, Target plan sales blitzes for evening of Thanksgiving Day Walmart, Target plan sales blitzes for evening of Thanksgiving Day A customer guides her shopping carts with televisions purchased at a Target Store in Colma, Calif., in 2011. (Jeff Chiu/AP) By SARAH HALZACK WASHINGTON POST Walmart and Target each plan to kick off their in-store Black Friday sales at 6 p.m. on Thanksgiving, repeating their start-times from last year and throwing some cold water on the notion that Turkey Day deals blitzes may be falling out of style. Earlier in the season, the Mall of America announced it would be shuttering its doors on the holiday after being open in previous years. Office Depot, too, made a similar reversal of course. But the plans from the big-box behemoths — as well as from Macy’s, Kohl’s and Toys R Us — suggest the Thanksgiving Day shopping tradition is going strong. Walmart said it will be “dramatically increasing” the amount of inventory it has available for online deal hunters, offering some 50 percent more Black Friday merchandise this year on the Web than last year. “We really pride ourselves on not being the retailer who advertises a great price but then only has a few available for the customers,” said Steve Bratspies, the chief merchandising officer at Walmart U.S., during a conference call with reporters. Walmart said its offerings this year would include items such as a Samsung 50-inch 4K television for $398 and movies that cost $1.99. Target, meanwhile, was touting deals such as an iPad Air 2 for $274 and 30 percent off apparel. Oh, and remember that giant $10 teddy bear that was all over social media last Black Friday? The retailer is bringing it back, and has bought 20 percent more inventory this time around. Both chains will start their online Black Friday sales in the early morning hours on Thanksgiving. And both will be offering a steady trickle of discounts over the next two weeks to encourage customers to get in the holiday spirit. In earlier announcements about their seasonal plans, Target and Walmart stressed they were trying to focus on making their promotions simple this time around. In the past, it seems, shoppers have been confused by a cavalcade of coupons or staggered sale starting times. At Target, that means returning to the “10 days of deals” program, something the retailer tried last year in which it touted a single big promotion each day starting the weekend before Thanksgiving. Walmart is also aiming for simple: Besides its limited-time Black Friday discounts, it plans to keep the rest of its price cuts in place for the duration of the November and December rush. The National Retail Federation, an industry trade group, forecasts that stores will ring up a healthy 3.6 percent increase in sales this holiday season. That would be an improvement from last year, when sales growth was up just 3 percent. We should soon get a clearer idea of what kind of momentum big retail has headed into this all-important time of year: Macy’s is set to report earnings Thursday morning, and Walmart, Target, Best Buy and others will do so in the following week. 100 Restaurants Warriors show their style off the court MenuSections http://www.sfgate.com/business/article/Retailers-expect-more-Black-Friday-deal-hunters-10608867.php Retailers expect more Black Friday deal hunters online Chicago Tribune Published 1:10 pm, Friday, November 11, 2016 Walmart is bracing for big Black Friday crowds — especially online. The retailer, known for stampedes at its front doors in the wee hours of Black Friday morning, is changing a tried-and-true formula to attract shoppers surfing the Internet from the comfort of their homes in their pajamas. This year, Walmart will increase the number of items with Black Friday discounts allocated to online shoppers by about 50 percent, said U.S. Chief Merchandising Officer Steve Bratspies. Black Friday deals will be available days before the calendar actually hits Nov. 25, diluting what was once a one-day, deal-hunting frenzy. And as retailers have begun offering the same promotions online, they’ve made the idea of braving in-store Black Friday crowds less compelling for some shoppers. “If you’re a retailer, it doesn’t matter where you’re getting your business from, just that you’re getting the business. (Making sales available online) is much more in tune with what the consumer is looking for,” said Neil Stern, senior partner at Chicago consulting firm McMillanDoolittle. Walmart isn’t alone. For the first time, J.C. Penney will make its Black Friday specials available online at midnight Nov. 22 — more than a day before shoppers can get them in stores at 3 p.m. on Thanksgiving. And Kohl’s is letting online shoppers in on its 6 p.m. Thanksgiving “door-buster” deals for the first time this year, too. Like last year, Walmart, Target and Sears will give online shoppers a head start. Black Friday prices will be available online in the early Thanksgiving morning hours and in stores at 6 p.m. on Thanksgiving. “We know that customers don’t exclusively shop in one channel — they shop online and in stores. Having omnichannel deals provides a consistent experience for our customers so they can shop any time and any way they choose,” said Kohl’s spokeswoman Melanie Hochschild. At some stores, such as J.C. Penney, Kohl’s and Sears, all Black Friday door-buster prices can be found online. Walmart will have most of those deals online, but some will still require a trip to the store. Target, J.C. Penney, Walmart, Kohl’s and Sears also offer certain online-only Black Friday deals before Thanksgiving through their apps and websites. Most people plan to start their holiday shopping before Black Friday week, and about 30 percent expect to make most of their purchases before the week begins, according to a survey by PricewaterhouseCoopers. And while the consulting firm expects fewer shoppers on Black Friday itself this year, that doesn’t mean stores will be quiet. Of the people who expect to shop during the week of Thanksgiving, a majority plan to do most of that spending on Black Friday. But more of the likely Black Friday and Thanksgiving shoppers surveyed by Accenture said they expect to shop online than in stores. in non-auto retail sales 1479216960 World Obama urges America not to unplug from global economy 1479214260 World Russian minister was detained at Rosneft offices: lawyer 1479223458 China China’s e-commerce giants battle it out for slice of online grocery market mail print View all comments Tweet Published: 4:00 AM, November 12, 2016 BEIJING — For China’s 720 million Internet users, websites run by the country’s two biggest e-commerce companies, Alibaba Group and JD.com, have become the preferred shopping destinations for everything from trendy clothing to tech gadgets. Now, the e-commerce behemoths are training their sights on everyday indispensables — groceries and household items. Over the past few months, both have poured hundreds of millions of yuan into a price war aimed at dragging shoppers away from supermarkets and corner stores. As sales of other goods reach saturation point for JD.com and Alibaba, groceries are the next battleground, said Ms Xu Xin, CEO of the venture capital firm Capital Today, which has invested in JD.com. Conquering the market for fresh food and other grocery items may eventually enable e-commerce companies to take control of as much as half of China’s total market for consumer goods sales, as Alibaba chairman Jack Ma predicted, Ms Xu said. In a letter to shareholders last year, Mr Ma declared that “over 50 per cent of China’s consumption will be conducted online within 10 years”. To reach that goal, “there will absolutely be a war between Alibaba and JD.com”, said Mr Cheng Shaoxiong, north China chief for the supermarket division of Tmall, Alibaba’s business-to-consumer site. He said online grocery sales are the last frontier for e-commerce companies. CHEAP, FAST COURIERS Online retail is flourishing in China, thanks to the country’s highly efficient and low-cost courier industry. Last year, online purchases accounted for 10.8 per cent of China’s 30 trillion yuan (S$6.15 trillion) in retail sales, a 32 per cent increase over the previous year, according to the National Statistics Bureau. For fast-moving consumer goods, including toiletries, soft drinks and fresh food, nearly 20 per cent of the purchases were made online. By 2020, online sales of fast-moving consumer goods will grow at a much faster pace than apparel and electronics to expand five-fold from today and reach 1.2 trillion yuan, according to Yihaodian, one of China’s pioneering online grocery sites. Fresh food and grocery items with quick turnover and higher profit margins have long been the competitive strength of large supermarket chains such as Wal-Mart and Yonghui Superstores. For e-commerce companies, moving into the sector requires heavy investments in logistics, warehousing and distribution. Alibaba and JD.com have made tit-for-tat moves to gain a foothold in the burgeoning online grocery market. On Oct 19, Alibaba and smaller rival Suning Commerce Group said they had established a new e-commerce joint venture with an investment of 1 billion yuan to manage Suning-owned stores on Alibaba sites. The venture is expected to combine the strengths of both companies. It is also a step forward for a partnership formed last year, when Alibaba became Suning’s second-largest shareholder through an equity swap. The next day, JD.com stepped up its partnership with Wal-Mart. It opened Wal-Mart-branded stores on JD.com, using its huge logistics network to offer fast deliveries for Wal-Mart in some cities. Wal-Mart also invested US$50 million (S$69.5 million) in the JD.com-backed online grocery specialist, New Dada. JD.com and Wal-Mart had formed a strategic alliance in June when Wal-Mart sold its China online grocery store, Yihaodian, to JD.com. Alibaba is the unrivalled titan in China’s online retail market. In the fiscal year ended in March, the company’s combined sales from its business-to-consumer site Tmall, consumer-to-consumer site Taobao and group-buying service Juhuasuan totalled 2.95 trillion yuan. That dwarfed JD.com’s sales of 462.7 billion yuan, generated mainly from business-to-consumer transactions. But JD.com is expanding at a faster pace. In the quarter between March and June, JD.com’s gross merchandise volume, a measurement of total sales value, grew 47 per cent from March to June a year earlier. Alibaba’s rose 24 per cent. “JD.com is coming within shooting range of Alibaba,” said a source close to Alibaba’s top management. Since the beginning of this year, Alibaba has set detailed monthly targets to counter JD.com, this individual said. Despite their healthy sales growth, both companies face the same challenge — a slower expansion of users after years of explosive growth. Alibaba had 423 million active users while JD.com has 188 million, according to company documents. TESTING THE WATERS Alibaba tested the supermarket waters in 2012 by launching Tmall grocery services in Shanghai and Hangzhou. But the “business proved to be very difficult due to high logistics costs”, said a former Yihaodian manager who declined to be named. It was not until July last year that the grocery business was listed as one of Alibaba’s four pillars of online retailing, along with Taobao, Tmall and Juhuasuan. That year, Alibaba spent 1 billion yuan in Beijing alone to subsidise grocery vendors and shoppers. Between 2012 and last year, Alibaba made heavy investments in logistics and warehouse facilities, enabling it to sell fresh produce, according to a staff member at Tmall. JD.com quickly set up its own online supermarket division in October last year. According to company financial reports, in the first quarter of this year, JD.com’s grocery sales rose 70 per cent from the previous year, while Alibaba’s supermarket sales grew 220 per cent. The expansion into groceries by the two e-commerce giants crushed smaller players. Wal-Mart-backed Yihaodian’s market share in the country’s e-commerce market shrank to less than 0.3 per cent in 2015 from 2.6 per cent in 2013, according to the e-commerce research website 100ec.cn. In the first quarter this year, the site barely recorded any growth from a year earlier. That prompted Wal-Mart to sell Yihaodian to JD.com in June in exchange for JD.com equity worth about US$1.5 billion. The strategic alliance with Wal-Mart is expected to give JD.com shoppers wider access to imported Wal-Mart products and provide more ammunition for JD.com’s battle with Alibaba. After the deal, JD.com announced a 1 billion yuan investment in Yihaodian over the next three months and an ambitious goal of developing JD.com as the largest grocery retailer in three years, according to JD.com vice-president Feng Yi. Alibaba quickly promised 2 billion yuan in subsidies for shoppers on its Tmall Supermarket site and 2 billion yuan of new investments to improve logistics and the supply chain. The price war has escalated since September as Tmall Supermarket poured 180 million yuan into discounts for grocery shoppers from Sept 1-9. At the same time, JD.com offered 50 per cent discounts on grocery items. Some experts have questioned the price-war strategy. “The gross profit margin of grocery items is less than 20 per cent,” said Li Chengdong, an independent e-commerce analyst. Offering such big discounts “is like burning money”. A source close to Tmall Supermarket said Alibaba can afford the discounting because of the parent group’s profitability. But concerns over heavy spending are greater for JD.com, which has yet to make a profit after 12 years in business. In June, JD.com’s share price on the New York Stock Exchange slumped to a historical low since its September 2014 listing. An APS Asset Management report had called money-losing JD.com “wildly overpriced”. The stock revived in August after the second-quarter financial report indicated a narrowing loss. Last year, JD.com lost US$1.4 billion, while Alibaba recorded a net profit of US$11.1 billion. FINE-TUNING STRATEGY After more than a decade, Alibaba and JD.com have developed distinct identities in online retailing. Alibaba’s Tmall and Taobao are the must-go places for many apparel shoppers because of their selection, offered by millions of vendors. JD.com has won more shoppers seeking branded electronic products. Alibaba has been focusing on operating platforms for numerous vendors and shoppers, while JD.com mainly sticks to direct sales backed by its highly effective, self-operated logistics network. But as the grocery war unfolds, both companies have sought to fine-tune their respective strategies and gradually move in each other’s direction. JD.com’s Mr Feng said the company’s supermarket division aims to challenge Alibaba’s strengths in cosmetics and apparel by expanding product variety. Meanwhile, Alibaba recently said it sees growth potential in home appliance and smartphone sales. The company has actively expanded using its logistics division, Cainiao, which now operates more than 128 warehouses across the country. Backed by Cainiao’s delivery capacity, Tmall Supermarket has adopted a JD.com-style direct-sales model, offering fresh produce sent directly from its own warehouse rather than a third-party supplier. At the same time, JD.com has been gradually changing its business structure by inviting more third-party vendors onto its platform. According to company data, third-party vendors accounted for 45 per cent of JD.com’s gross sales in the third quarter, up from 40 per cent a year ago. As the two companies’ strategies converge, both may increasingly face the same challenges, experts said. For instance, JD.com’s standardised customer services have long been blamed for a lack of interaction with shoppers, failing to lure users to surf among its product catalogue, as they usually do in Taobao and Tmall. At the same time, the huge number of vendors on Alibaba’s platforms has made controlling counterfeit or substandard products a longstanding headache. The e-commerce giants’ efforts to reshape their businesses echoed Alibaba chairman Ma’s call for e-commerce companies to adapt a radical change in the global retail industry as the boundary between online and offline sales becomes increasingly blurred. “In the coming years, we anticipate the birth of a reimagined retail industry driven by the integration of online, offline, logistics and data across a single value chain,” Mr Ma wrote to Alibaba shareholders in a letter last week. “With e-commerce itself rapidly becoming a ‘traditional business,’ pure e-commerce players will soon face tremendous challenges. This is why we are adapting.” CAIXIN mail print View all comments Tweet Recommended For You   More Stories For You The Most China&India READ COMMENTED “India really means business”: Iswaran ‘World’s cheapest smartphone’ to be launched in India ‘Voldemort’ attacks up ante in China-Japan propaganda war ‘Uncultured’ youth misled by religious extremists to blame for Tiananmen attack ‘This is our country!’ says Chinese official as Obama lands World Bank probe into Tata tea project finds it failed to protect Indian workers Workers laying roads in southern India rescued from debt bondage Trump, China's Xi establish sense of mutual respect: Trump statement Taiwan’s ruling party urges China to respect Hong Kong’s democratic aspirations Taiwan's ruling party urges China to respect Hong Kong's democratic aspirations Smog lifts, but companies' view of polluted Delhi skies is dim Moving to Shanghai? (Photo by Elaine Thompson, The Associated Press) The state's voters passed Prop. 67, the plastic ban bag, but O.C. bucked the trend. (Photo by Elaine Thompson, The Associated Press) By DAVID WHITING / STAFF COLUMNIST Facebook Twitter Email Comments PRINT SEND PDF The Walmart cashier tosses groceries so fast into a plastic bag turnstile, it spins like a merry-go-round. A box of a dozen Clif Bars, one bag. Walmart’s raisin bran, the next bag. Bananas, another bag. Three items, three plastic bags. I’m in bag heaven. But my wife – who thinks we can’t keep treating the planet like a garbage dump – is horrified. Yet in a surprising twist to Tuesday’s elections, she’s in the minority in Orange County. Yes, California voters last week easily approved Proposition 67, the plastic bag ban. Yet in Orange County, voters overwhelmingly made it clear we love our plastic bags. Statewide, 52 percent of voters agreed it’s time to stop spreading around thin bits of plastic. In Orange County, a whopping 58.6 percent of voters said keep the plastic. For a county with a fragile diversity of wildlands, streams, estuaries, beaches, tide pools, ocean, it’s time to understand why the state’s plastic bag ban makes serious sense. That’s especially true for us plastic bag lovers. O.C. JOINS MAINSTREAM, ALMOST Know-nothings scoff at Orange County bucking the environmental awareness trend. Republicans, they say, don’t care about bags that destroy ecosystems, kill birds, harm fish. That’s silly. Plenty of Republicans are environmentalists. But even if environmental issues were divided along political lines, the Orange County of today is far different than the Orange County of my grandparents. In last week’s election, more people in the O.C. voted for Hillary Clinton than Donald Trump. That’s right, the county with an airport named after John Wayne and home to the library and museum of Richard Nixon is Clinton country. Put another way, Orange County is no longer an outlier in California politics. For better or worse, we’ve joined the Golden State’s mainstream. Orange County followed statewide voting patterns in 13 of the 17 initiatives. We said yes to marijuana; we decided porn stars don’t need to wear condoms; we even voted for further restrictions on firearms and ammunition. But – oddly – when it came to plastic bags, only 323,378 of us said ban them. Another 458,527 said keep them. My review of precinct breakdowns found that the only clusters in Orange County where the bag ban initiative flourished was near UCI and in Laguna Beach. Reasons vary for our love affair with plastic bags. We use them for lunch, for storage. Many of us like plastic bags because we think they are convenient. Some – like me – use them to scoop up dog poop. When I cleaned up after two dogs, it seemed like I couldn’t get enough of what I thought of as free bags. But nothing’s free. The plastic bag industry in California is an estimated $15 million a year business. It’s no surprise that a pro-bag lobby called the American Progressive Bag Alliance spent millions of dollars to delay SB 270, a bill approved by the California legislature a few years ago to ban bags. That’s right. The initiative we voted on last week was a do-over. With plastic bags going away, I decided to give cloth bags a try. Guess what? Other than having to remember to bring the darn things, I discovered I like cloth bags. Unlike plastic bags and the corresponding busted milk jugs, cloth bags don’t break. Best of all, they hold more groceries – and that means fewer trips from the car to the kitchen. A lot fewer trips. That’s just the beginning. JUST ONE WORD – PLASTICS There are 42 miles of beachfront in Orange County and if you’ve ever walked the sand, swam offshore, surfed, then you probably have hollered, “jellyfish,” only to discover a very yucky plastic bag. Bill Hickman is Southern California regional manager for the Surfrider Foundation, a nonprofit that focuses on ocean and beach. One of its main missions is to reduce single-use plastics and increase the recycling of all plastics. That includes banning plastic bags. I tick off Orange County’s voting numbers for Proposition 67 and Hickman admits, “It’s frustrating Orange County hasn’t come around.” Despite the promise of plastics in the classic film “The Graduate,” Hickman explains when it rains, plastics are swept to the beaches along concrete riverbeds and into the ocean by storm drains. “Those little plastic bags are an immediate threat to wildlife, sea turtles.” The regional director lives in Ventura County and once spotted a cormorant that had been strangled by a plastic bag. So with the bag ban, should I buy those blue dog poop bags? Hickman says blue bags aren’t much better – unless they end up in an industrial dump. Instead, he offers a free solution: Look around, it’s surprising how many bags we have – bread bags, produce bags, bags from cereal boxes. Hickman offers another reason Orange County voters said no to the bag ban: We bought into the bag lobby’s claim that the bag ban is a money grab. Ouch. But according to ballotpedia.com, “Supporters raised $3.66 million, while opponents received $6.14 million. Most of the opposition’s funds came from plastic bag companies.” The state’s official election guide offers this official statement from Proposition 67 opponents: “It is a $300 million per year hidden tax increase on California consumers who will be forced to pay a minimum 10 cents for every paper and thick plastic grocery bag they are given at the checkout.” That may be true – but not if we bring our own bags. I suggest cloth. No profanity, vulgarity, racial slurs or personal attacks. People who harass others or joke about tragedies will be blocked. By posting your comment, you agree to allow Orange County Register Communications, Inc. the right to republish your name and comment in additional Register publications without any notification or payment. More attacks, or more sensitivity? One retailer that has paved the way for the annual shopping event is US retail giant Walmart , who also own UK supermarket ASDA . In recent years the store's sale has sparked chaos and violence and shoppers fight for the bargains. But if you're planning to steer clear of the madness and shop online, Walmart's Black Friday deals will launch on Walmart's website at 12:01 AM Eastern Time on 24th November, and stores will open from 6pm. IS. TARGET. Shop manager's hilariously dram Video will play in  Share this video Watch Next What deals to expect? From cut price games consoles to discounted tablets and smartphones, Walmart's leaked Black Friday deals mark a strong list of coveted tech and electrical items. If you're a serious gamer you're in for a treat, Walmart are set to have the PS4 Slim console bundle with Unchartered 4 game and $30 gift card for just $249. Gamers will be able to get their hands on the PS4 slim in the sale While Xbox One fans can save $50 off the Xbox One S console Battlefield bundle , bringing the price down to £249. Top video games, including FIFA 17 and Battlefield 1 , will also be on sale for $27 - saving customers $32 off the normal RRP. Apple iPhone 5S will be $99 (Photo: Reuters) Apple products will also make an appearance in the Black Friday discounts, with the 16GB Apple iPhone 5s down to $99 and the 32GB iPad Mini 2 priced at $199 - saving shoppers $70 off. Other standout offers we've spotted include 4K TVs starting from $398 for a 50 inch. Walmart Releases 2016 Black Friday Ad and Offers Early Online Deals Posted on November 11, 2016 Tweet Walmart has revealed its 2016 Black Friday ad. Walmart stores will open at 6 p.m. on Thanksgiving Day for the Black Friday sale. Most of the Black Friday deals will also be available online at 12:01 a.m. ET on Thanksgiving morning. You can find the ad here on walmart.com. Steve Bratspies, chief merchandising officer, Walmart U.S, says in a statement, "I said it before and I will say it again, we will win the season on price – on Black Friday, on Cyber Monday and every day before and after. That means delivering the Black Friday deals we're known for in stores, online and on our app. And, we've secured significant availability of these items. We pride ourselves on not being the retailer who advertises a great price and then only has a few available." Here are a few highlights of the Black Friday deals: DJI Drone Phantom Standard 3 - $369 Element or Emerson 50-inch HDTV - $225 Element or Hisense 40-inch HDTV - $125 Fitbit Alta - $99 Fitbit Charge 2 - $129 Fitbit Flex 2 - $69 Hatchimals - $48.88 HP 15.6-inch Touch Laptop - $249 iPad Mini 2 32GB - $199 Nest 3rd Generation Learning Thermostat - $199 Phillips 55-inch Smart 4KTV - $298 PlayStation 4 Slim Uncharted 4 500GB Bundle + $30 Gift Card - $249 Promark 3D Virtual Reality HD Drone - $99 Razor Hovertrax 2.0 Hoverboard - $273 Samsung 50-inch Smart 4KTV - $398 Samsung Chromebook 3 - $119 Sharper Image Video Drone - $30 Vizio 60-inch HDTV - $398 Xbox One S White 500GB Battlefield Bundle - $249 Walmart has also made some of its Black Friday deals available early. You can find the early deals here. They include a Hitachi 65-inch 4K Ultra HDTV for $599, Acer 15.6-inch Core i5 Laptop for $299, Cricut Explore One Special Edition Bluetooth Bundle for $169, Lifetime 44-inch Portable Basketball Hoop for $69 and and Fisher-Price Tough Trike for $19. Technology Apple Science Cars Celebrity Movies Business Black Friday Holiday Gifts     $99 New Nintendo 3DS Black Friday Deal Shows Up At Walmart Posted: Nov 11 2016, 6:56am CST | by Luigi Lugmayr, Updated: Nov 13 2016, 7:54am CST, in News | Black Friday   This story may contain affiliate links.   Buy This Now On Amazon The announced $99 New Nintendo 3DS Black Friday Edition shows up in Walmart online store. Nintendo announced a $99.99 New Nintendo 3DS console for Black Friday 2016 earlier this week. The two special-edition Black Friday Nintendo 3DS models, one black, one white are now listed in the Walmart online store. How To: Find Pokemon Go Plus In Stock Walmart will as often is the case shave off 99c of the Nintendo suggested price. The white $99 New Nintendo 3DS is listed here and the black $99 New Nintendo 3DS is listed here. The title of the listings is a bit curious. Walmart calls the $99 3DS "New Nintendo 3DS Super Mario Edition." The 3DS is decorated with Mushroom Kingdom characters and imagery. Why Walmart calls it Super Mario is unclear.  The New Nintendo 3DS system combines portable gaming in a compact size with 3D technology, added control features and interchangeable Cover Plates. Take 3D photos, connect with friends, and enhance your gaming experiences with added amiibo support. The 3DS is recommended for kids seven and older, because of the 3D display. Walmart is known break sales embargoes, but we don't believe that Walmart will start to sell the New Nintendo 3DS before Nov. 25, Black Friday 2016. In an earlier report we compare the new $99 New Nintendo 3DS to other 3DS bundles. There is good chance that there will be a better deal on a New Nintendo 3DS XL with game comes in at a better deal. The new 3DS under $100 does not come with a free game. The Target Black Friday 2016 Ad is featuring the $99.99 New Nintendo 3DS, but is not listing it yet in their online store. Walmart's Black Friday 2016 ad does not advertise the 3DS Black Friday deal. Amazon will offer the new 3DS Black Friday deal, but has not listed this new Nintendo 3DS yet. The Walmart Black Friday 2016 sale begins midnight on Thanksgiving Day online and at 6pm in stores. You can browse the full 36-pages of the Walmart Black Friday 2016 Ad online. Walmart will once again open on Thanksgiving Day. The 6pm store opening time is the same as last year. Wristbands for doorbuster deals could be handed out as early as 2 hours before the Walmart Black Friday 2016 sale begins. Ask at your local Walmart store when wristbands have been handed out last year to prepare your shopping schedule. The big three Black Friday 2016 ads are released. Walmart, Target and Best Buy released their highly anticipated Black Friday 2016 ads on November 10. Find all released Black Friday 2016 ads in our Black Friday ads list. We have compiled everything you need to know about Black Friday 2016 in our Black Friday 2016 guide. Browse the big three Black Friday 2016 ads below: Walmart Black Friday 2016 Ad Target Black Friday 2016 ad Best Buy Black Friday 2016 ad Read also everything we know about the Amazon Black Friday 2016 sale, which we predict will be largest Black Friday sale in history. Black Friday 2016 is on November 25. Read the latest Black Friday 2016 news. He started I4U News back in 2000 and evolved it into vibrant technology magazine. November 11, 2016 08:00 ET Orbital Tracking Corp. Reports Third Quarter 2016 Financial Results Quarterly Revenue Grows 32%, Reaching Record Levels Driven by Strong EU Sales Despite Ongoing Currency Devaluations AVENTURA, FL--(Marketwired - November 11, 2016) - Orbital Tracking Corp. (OTCQB: TRKK) ("Orbital Tracking" or the "Company"), today reported financial results for the three and nine months ended September 30, 2016. Third Quarter 2016 Highlights In August, Global Telesat Communications Ltd. ("GTCL"), the Company's wholly owned subsidiary, was selected by the Electoral Commission of Zambia ("ECZ") to provide more than 200 satellite phones, satellite broadband terminals, associated airtime and customer support services to ECZ and its staff during the country's presidential elections which took place on August 11th. This is the largest sale of its kind awarded to GTCL in Africa. In September, Orbital Satcom Corp. ("OSC"), the Company's U.S.-based wholly owned subsidiary, expanded its North American online retail channel through Walmart's invite-only Marketplace at www.walmart.com. The Walmart online marketplace joins a growing list of U.S.-based e-commerce marketplaces operated by Orbital Tracking under the OSC brand including sites on Amazon.com, eBay and Sears.com. "We are pleased with the top-line growth recorded in the third quarter of 2016, traditionally one of the Company's strongest, as sales volumes reached record levels. Demand in our global markets in Europe remained high and were bolstered by significant new contracts in emerging markets such as in Africa with the ECZ and in the US as we continue to expand our presence in North America," said David Phipps, Chief Executive Officer of Orbital Tracking Corp. "Our global growth plans for Orbital Tracking Corp. remain on track despite the continued negative impact of devaluation of the GBP is having on GTC sales and our margins as reported in our financial results. We continue to invest in the business, expanding both our product portfolio and market reach which will help mitigate continued currency volatility while helping ensure we continue to deliver the best satellite communications and tracking solutions available combined with unmatched service and support that our customers expect." Third Quarter 2016 Financial Results For the three months ended September 30, 2016, consolidated revenues reached record levels, increasing 32% to approximately $1,299,373 as compared to approximately $982,775 as reported for the quarter ended September 30, 2015. Consolidated revenues for the nine months ended September 30, 2016 increased 28% to approximately $3,783,230 vs approximately $2,955,453 reported in the comparable 2015 period. Although product volume sales were at record levels during the third quarter, results continued to show the negative impact of depreciation in the GBP and EUR against the US$. Comparable revenue for the Company's wholly owned subsidiaries, GTCL and Orbital Satcom Corp.("OSC"), increased 53.5% to approximately $998,878 and decreased 1.6% to approximately $326,833, respectively for the three months ended September 30, 2016. Total GTCL sales for the nine months ended September 30, 2016, increased 34% to approximately $2,082,863. Total sales for OSC for the nine months ended September 30, 2016, increased 13.6% to approximately $991,422. The Company recorded net loss before income tax of approximately $338,672 for the three months ended September 30, 2016 as compared to a net loss of $300,584, for the three months ended September 30, 2015. For the nine months ended September 30, 2016, the Company recorded a net loss of $1,452,463 as compared to a net loss of $955,185. The increase in losses for the nine months ended September 30, 2016, is attributable to interest and professional fees related to the Company's convertible debt and preferred share subscriptions in December 2015, offset by a decrease in stock based compensation. About Orbital Tracking Corp. Orbital Tracking Corp. provides satellite based tracking, services as well as mobile voice and data communications services globally via satellite to the commercial and government users. Orbital specializes in services related to the Globalstar satellite constellation, including ground station construction, simplex tracking services and satellite telecommunications voice airtime. Orbital operates various e-commerce retail and tracking portals where users around the world can purchase satellite hardware and track assets in real-time on mobile devices or PCs. For more information regarding Orbital, please visit www.OrbitalTracking.com. Forward-Looking Statements Certain statements in this release constitute forward-looking statements. These statements include the capabilities and success of the Company's business and any of its products, services or solutions. The words "believe," "forecast," "project," "intend," "expect," "plan," "should," "would," and similar expressions and all statements, which are not historical facts, are intended to identify forward-looking statements. These forward-looking statements involve and are subject to known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other factors, any of which could cause the Company to not achieve some or all of its goals or the Company's previously reported actual results, performance (finance or operating) to change or differ from future results, performance (financing and operating) or achievements, including those expressed or implied by such forward-looking statements. More detailed information about the Company and the risk factors that may affect the realization of forward-looking statements is set forth in the Company's filings with the SEC, copies of which may be obtained from the SEC's website at www.sec.gov. The Company assumes no, and hereby disclaims any, obligation to update the forward-looking statements contained in this press release. Contact Information Contacts: Michael Glickman MWGCO, Inc. 917-397-2272 mike@mwgco.net   View Desktop Version Pour voir la version complète
Home All News Calvert County News Charles County News St. Mary’s County News Prince George’s News Anne Arundel News Traffic Cameras Law Enforcement Crime Solvers Calvert County Crime Solvers Charles County Crime Solvers St. Mary’s County Crime Solvers Fire & Rescue Obituaries Weather Community Politics Department of Defense Education Entertainment Arts Food Food Reviews Music Night Life MORE Business Opinions Commentary Editorials Letters Sports St. Mary’s County Crime Solvers High School Sports Motor Sports About Us Advertise Contact Us Wednesday’s Pet Good News FIRE/POLICE SCANNERS Food Reviews Newly Remodeled Walmart Supercenter in Prince Frederick Celebrates Grand Reopening November 11, 2016 Ceremony to highlight store upgrades, commitment to community on Nov. 11 The newly remodeled Walmart Store located at 150 Solomons Island Road, in Prince Frederick ,will host a grand reopening celebration on Friday, Nov. 11 at 7 a.m. The project represents Walmart’s reinvestment in the store, its customers, and the community. The remodel provides expanded hardware and automotive departments, a refreshed electronics department and six new self-checkout stations. Customers will also appreciate improved customer service areas, including Money Services and Walmart Pickup. Shopping is more convenient than ever as Prince Frederick residents can shop millions of items on Walmart.com, many of which can be shipped for free to any Walmart store through Walmart Pickup. The store also has a remodeled pharmacy with a full range of products and services and immunizations offered in a private consultation room. Walmart pharmacists are ready to assist customers with product and prescription questions. Prince Frederick residents can easily transfer prescriptions and order refills on the go with the Walmart mobile app. “We are looking forward to re-introducing our store to the community with expanded offerings and a fresh look. Our everyday low prices will remain the same, but we’re adding greater convenience and a new and improved local grocery shopping experience,” said Tim Crowley, store manager. Join the Grand Opening Celebration Local associates will provide a special welcome to members of the Prince Frederick community with a grand reopening celebration. A brief ribbon-cutting ceremony will be held on Friday, Nov. 11, at 7 a.m. followed by family activities and free food samples while supplies last. On Saturday, Nov. 12 from 10 a.m. – noon and Sunday, Nov. 13, from noon to 5 p.m., customers can enjoy a grand reopening event with sampling and family friendly activities and special guests, the Prince Frederick police and fire department that will offer safety tips and fire prevention information. Job Opportunities At Walmart, associates have access to competitive wages, affordable benefits and the chance to build a career. More than 75% of store management teams started as hourly associates, and 40 percent of those promotions went to associates within the first year of their employment. Committed to the Community Walmart is committed to serving the Prince Frederick community and will support organizations through an approximate $2,000 investment in the coming months. The commitment to community goes beyond philanthropy. This investment is a whole company undertaking that is woven into Walmart’s day-to-day business activities, creating value by accelerating job mobility, developing suppliers and small businesses, lowering the environmental footprint of Walmart’s operations and more.   This entry was posted on November 11, 2016 at 7:18 am and is filed under All News, Business, Calvert News, Community, County, More News, Press Releases, z 600X120 Top Ad Top. You can follow any responses to this entry through the RSS 2.0 feed. Leave a Reply Cancel reply Your email address will not be published. Technology Apple Science Cars Celebrity Movies Business Black Friday Holiday Gifts     Black Friday 2016: How To Get Started Posted: Nov 11 2016, 3:03am CST | by Luigi Lugmayr, in News | Black Friday   This story may contain affiliate links. Black Friday 2016. Credit: Getty Images   The Black Friday 2016 sale is coming up in less than two weeks. The amount of advertised Black Friday deals is staggering. Here is how to get started. Black Friday 2016 is in two weeks from today. On Thursday popular retailers released hundreds of pages of Black Friday 2016 ads. Advertised Black Friday 2016 deals range from a $199.99 49-inch Toshiba 4K HDTV to $48.88 Hatchimals. Finding the deals that Black Friday shoppers want is the challenge.  How To: Find Pokemon Go Plus In Stock To get started browse the popular Black Friday ads from Walmart, Best Buy and Target to get a feel for what these prime destinations for Black Friday offer this year. Other popular Black Friday ads can be found here. The next step is to make a list of the deals that are attractive and fit your shopping list. Then we recommend to check the current deal on the products. There is a chance that the items are already on sale now. A good starting point that most consumers are already using is amazon.com. Once it is clear that the desired items are only on sale on Black Friday, it is time to make a schedule. Many retailers begin in store sales on Thanksgiving Day. The online Black Friday 2016 sales start as early as Wednesday before Thanksgiving. It is advisable to first try to score deals in the online Black Friday 2016 sales before heading out into the cold Thanksgiving Day evening to line-up for doorbuster deals. Sam's Club is giving Black Friday shoppers a head start on Saturday in a 24 hour sale that offers the first wave of Sam's Club Black Friday 2016 deals. Purchasing deals early, frees shoppers up during crunch time on Thanksgiving Day. Advertised doorbuster deals will in most cases only be available in stores. This year more doorbuster deals than ever will be also available online. Especially in the case of the Walmart, Best Buy and Target Black Friday 2016 sale events, it is advantages to work in teams. Walmart discontinued the 1-Hour Guarantee deals. Doorbuster deals are only available to shoppers who have been early in line for wirstbands. With a team, Black Friday deal hunters can divide and conquer. If you plan on snatching a $48.88 Hatchimals deal at the Walmart Black Friday 2016 sale, assign the strongest of your team to the task. It might get ugly. To help get your Black Friday 2016 shopping list started refer to the following Black Friday 2016 deals guides: Best Sam's Club Black Friday 2016 Deals All Walmart Black Friday 2016 TV Deals Black Friday 2016 4K TV Deals at Walmart, Best Buy and Target Best Black Friday 2016 HDR 4K TV Deals Best Stores to Buy Hatchimals Sears and Kmart Black Friday 2016 TV Deals Amazon Black Friday 2016 Deals Outlook Black Friday 2016 updates are rolling in each day now. Find the latest Black Friday 2016 news in the Black Friday section. Recover your password Home Our Team Contact Us Black Friday Magazine Get the best Black Friday Alerts Before Anyone Else Home Sales Black Friday Walmart Reveals Black Friday Deals Sales Black Friday Deals Walmart Walmart Reveals Black Friday Deals By Linda Cauthen - November 11, 2016 94 0 SHARE Facebook Twitter Walmart stores are notorious for drawing huge crowds with their infamous Black Friday doorbuster deals so over the last few years, the mega-chain has been making it easier for bargain hunters to shop online by offering more hot deals online and starting the Black Friday madness early. This year Walmart has debuted some of its most tempting deals on TVs, toys, electronics and more on its smartphone app so savvy shoppers can get a head start on their holiday gift lists. Stores will open at 6 p.m. on Thanksgiving and there will be a few items available only at the brick-and-mortar locations but you may be able to find everything you’ve been looking for at Walmart.com where you can shop all day Thursday, November 24. Here’s a taste of the Black Friday deals to check out at Walmart. TVs Hot deals on big-screen TVs include a Samsung 50” Smart 4KTV for $398, a discount of $230. Walmart also offers four Special Buys: a Phillips 55” Smart 4KTV for $298, a Vizio 60” HDTV for $298, a 50” HDTV for $225 and a 40” HDTV for $125. The brands on the last two were not named and will vary from store to store. Plus a 40” Hisense or Class Element HDTV is also $125. If you choose a non-smart TV, you can still stream hundreds of movies and TV shows with the Roku Express Plus, now just $25. Complete the entertainment package with a Sanyo Blu-ray disc player for $35. Hundreds of DVD titles are on sale starting at just $1.96 and Blu-ray titles starting at $5.96. Gaming Walmart is always one of the best places to score the lowest price on all things gaming and this year is no exception. Sure to be a hit it is a PlayStation 4 Slim Uncharted 4 500GB bundle with $30 gift card for $249, a saving of $50. The XBox One S 500GB white Battlefield bundle is also on sale for $250, a discount of $50. Select top video game titles are now $27 each, a discount of $32.88. This includes assorted newly-released video games. Walmart stores will be offering wristbands for select items to in-store customers two hours ahead of time. If you want to avoid the in-store pandemonium altogether, you can purchase these sale items directly from your app: a Hitachi 65” 4K Ultra HDTV for $599, a Cricut Explore One Special Edition Bluetooth Bundle for $169 and a Bounce Pro 7′ Trampoline for $79. There are 36 pages of Black Friday deals on toys, smartphones, tablets, laptops, apparel and more on the Walmart app, available for iPhone or Android. For more savings, look for Daily Deals at Walmart.com. County Road 150W, Trafalgar: A man reported at 2:40 p.m. Wednesday that someone made fraudulent charges on his account. Technology Apple Science Cars Celebrity Movies Business Black Friday Holiday Gifts     Hatchimals Walmart Black Friday Deal Is Most Surprising Posted: Nov 11 2016, 12:41am CST | by Luigi Lugmayr, Updated: Nov 13 2016, 8:43am CST, in News | Black Friday   This story may contain affiliate links.   Buy This Now On Amazon The Hatchimals Black Friday deal advertised in the Walmart Black Friday 2016 Ad raises a lot of questions. The Walmart Black Friday 2016 Ad advertises Hatchimals for $48.88. This is a head-scratcher as Hatchimals are the hottest holiday toy of 2016 and are sold out for the most part. Don't Miss: Best Amazon Black Friday 2016 Deals Walmart's Black Friday event has a dramatic scale. The retail giant operates over 5,000 stores in the United States. For Walmart to decide to feature Hatchimals in their ad needs be based on a the availability of a very large inventory of Hatchimals.  Hatchimals Eggs are on sale for the Black Friday price already now at walmart.com, but to find the deal in stock is difficult. As reported, I managed to find a $48.88 Hatchimal online at walmart.com earlier this week. Spin Master, maker of Hatchimals, has warned consumers that the demand for Hatchimals is outpacing demand in the Holiday season and sets exceptions for increased supply coming in 2017. Walmart must be hoarding Hatchimals in their warehouses for the Walmart Black Friday sale.  There is no information about how many Hatchimals Eggs each Walmart store will have in stock and if the Hatchimals Black Friday deal will also be available online as it is now, in case there is stock. Walmart did mention the $48.88 Hatchimals Black Friday deal in the Black Friday 2016 ad announcement, which gives the deal additional attention. Walmart knows based on their decades of Black Friday sales experience, that things can quickly go wrong when extremely popular deals are in short supply in stores. We have seen physical violence as recently as last year of shoppers fighting for items in Walmart stores. The Hatchimals Black Friday deal is prone to trigger out of control situation. Hatchimals resell for about $150 on Amazon and eBay. This means that not just parents will be gunning for the Hatchimals in the Walmart Black Friday sale, it will be scalpers as well. Prices of Hatchimals are likely still to increase closer to the Holidays. Depending on the amount of Hatchimals coming into the reseller market after Black Friday, there might be a brief drop in prices.  So far only Walmart has announced Black Friday Hatchimals deals. Target for instance did not decide to advertise Hatchimals in the Target Black Friday 2016 Ad. We have a feeling that the ToysRUs Black Friday 2016 Ad will feature Hatchimals. ToysRUs has a history of offering hard to find holiday toys as doorbusters on Black Friday. Update: The ToysRUs Black Friday 2016 Ad just leaked and does not advertise Hatchimals. Walmart is so far the only store to offer Hatchimals on Black Friday. The Walmart Black Friday 2016 sale begins midnight on Thanksgiving Day online and at 6pm in stores. You can browse the full 36-pages of the Walmart Black Friday 2016 Ad online. Walmart will once again open on Thanksgiving Day. The 6pm store opening time is the same as last year. Wristbands for doorbuster deals could be handed out as early as 2 hours before the Walmart Black Friday 2016 sale begins. Ask at your local Walmart store when wristbands have been handed out last year to prepare your shopping schedule. The big three Black Friday 2016 ads are released. Walmart, Target and Best Buy released their highly anticipated Black Friday 2016 ads on November 10. Find all released Black Friday 2016 ads in our Black Friday ads list. We have compiled everything you need to know about Black Friday 2016 in our Black Friday 2016 guide. Browse the big three Black Friday 2016 ads below: Walmart Black Friday 2016 Ad Target Black Friday 2016 ad Best Buy Black Friday 2016 ad Read also everything we know about the Amazon Black Friday 2016 sale, which we predict will be largest Black Friday sale in history. Black Friday 2016 is on November 25. Read the latest Black Friday 2016 news. Smith 69° Low 48° High 76° Fayetteville 71° Low 45° High 74° Bentonville 66° Low 48° High 73° See complete forecast Walmart Tests Pickup Vending Machine At Rogers Store Posted 9:22 pm, November 10, 2016, by Bryan Shawver, Updated at 10:14pm, November 10, 2016 Share this: Facebook Twitter Google Pinterest LinkedIn Email Please enable Javascript to watch this video ROGERS (KFSM) -- Walmart has created a large vending machine in hopes of reeling in the largest generational group in the country. The pickup machine, which remains without an official name, is playing catch up to the changing ways that millennials are shopping at retailers. Stationed inside Walmart store number one, off Walnut Street in Rogers, the large orange pick up machine is hard to miss. It currently is the only one located in any Walmart around the world, and remains in test mode. A growing demand for online shopping and picking purchases up in-store has the retail giant finding ways to streamline the process. "We're jumping up from one or two [in-store pickups] a day to 15 to 20," said Justin Wright, manager of the pickup department. "That's just pickups today." Only general merchandise, which excludes grocery items, can be added to the machine. The process starts when a pickup order is submitted online to the Walnut St. location in Rogers. Employees are then notified and retrieve items for the order, wrap it or box it, and then put it in the machine. "As soon as it's been processed and BIN'd, the customer will be notified within 15 to 20 minutes," Wright said. "When they arrive, they'll check in and an employee will help get their order." Wright said that in other stores, pickup items are behind the customer service desk, but using the pickup vending machine has already proved to be a time-saver for both employees and customers. No extra cost for using the service is added to a customers bill. "It helps the customer, in and out, even if they're done shopping, they can pick their stuff up," Wright said. "It's very time saving, and it doesn't keep your associates locked down so they can help in other spots." Email to a friend Your email address Your friend's address Subject Body Check out this article Muslim Woman Told to 'Hang Herself' with Hijab at Walmart. http://www.snopes.com/muslim-woman-told-to-hang-herself-with-hijab-at-walmart/ Sent via snopes.com Send What's New Fact Checks News Hot 25 Newsletter Archive Glossary Contact Message Board FAQ Random Autos Business Cokelore College Computers Crime Critter Country Disney Embarrassments Entertainment Fake News Fauxtography Food Fraud & Scams Glurge Gallery History Holidays Horrors Humor Inboxer Rebellion Language Legal Affairs Lost Legends Love Luck Media Matters Medical Military Old Wives' Tales Politics Quotes Racial Rumors Religion Risquè Business Science September 11 Sports Technology Travel Viral Phenomena Weddings Submit A Rumor Go Go Home News Political News Muslim Woman Told to 'Hang Herself' with Hijab at Walmart Islamophobia on Aisle Five A woman's uncorroborated Facebook post describing the alleged incident has been shared thousands of times. Arturo Garcia Updated: Nov 11, 2016 Share - - Claim: A woman pulled a Muslim woman's hijab inside a Walmart and told her, "Go hang yourself with it around your neck." unproven Example: [Collected via Email, November 2016] Origin:On 9 November 2016, a Muslim woman named Maha Abdul Gawad posted the following story on Facebook of a confrontation she alleged took place at a WalMart store in the immediate aftermath of the 2016 presidential election won by Donald Trump: My first racist encounter after our new joke of a president, as I am at Wallmart [sic] today a woman came up to me and pulled my Hijab of and said "this is not allowed anymore, so go hang yourself with it around your neck not on your head" I am traumtized. [sic] He post was soon shared thousands of times and was also posted on Walmart's Facebook timeline. The company has not responded to that post, but a company spokesperson told snopes.com on 10 November 2016 that they was trying to establish contact with Gawad to obtain more information about the alleged incident. Walmart also sent snopes.com the following statement on 11 November 2016: We take what has been alleged seriously We attempted to look into this matter but have been unable to verify that the claim posted to Facebook by a customer actually took place, and the page has been removed. Gawad has not responded to our request for an interview. Police in her community (which we will not reveal to protect her safety) said they had not been contacted regarding such an encounter. Gawad's post is one of several stories of anti-Islam (and other) harassment that have circulated online since Donald Trump was elected president. Another Muslim woman described a similar incident in New Mexico on Twitter, in a post that has been shared more than 17,000 times. Guys, a trump supporter tried pulling off my hijab... This is not a joke anymore, all non-whites have become targets. Stay safe ? — bye (@Palestixian) November 9, 2016 The Council on American Islamic Relations (CAIR), a leading American Muslim advocacy group, has already called on Trump to "repudiate" such attacks. The group's communications director, Ibrahim Hooper, told us: We're hoping that perhaps Donald Trump as president will be different than he was while campainging for the presidency. We'll just have to see. We're just gonna maintain our defense of civil rights and religious freedom and any time those rights are challenged, we're gonna speak up and take legal action. Hooper did note that one woman recanted her initial account of an attack at the University of Louisiana at Lafayette. But even that case, he said, could be connected to an increase in phone calls CAIR has received from Muslim Americans facing mental health issues: I think it is symptomatic of the real anxiety and stress in the American Muslim community. It kind of brings this issues to the surface.
