Tech News Home > Tech > Tech News < Back to SMG 45 Thursday, 10 November 2016 | MYT 5:25 PM Wal-Mart boosts online holiday inventory for Black Friday Go big or go home: In an example of Wal-Mart's purchasing scale, the retailer has stocked more than 1.5 million televisions and 3 million videogames, Bratspies said. — Reuters CHICAGO: Wal-Mart Stores Inc will boost its online inventory for Black Friday by more than half this year and make deals available on its website early Thanksgiving morning, as it pulls out all stops to grow online sales this holiday season.  Wal-Mart's step to boost online products also comes at a time when Black Friday, the day after Thanksgiving which traditionally kicks off the year-end shopping season, is losing importance as the busiest shopping day of the year as early discounts and online shopping keep shoppers away from stores.  The year-end shopping season, which spans November and December, is crucial for many retailers because the two months can account for anywhere from 20 to 40% of their annual sales. The National Retail Federation expects industry holiday sales to grow 3.6% this year to US$655.8bil (RM2.79tril).  In order to avoid running out of stock on popular holiday items, which is a problem for many retailers, Wal-Mart has sufficiently stocked itself with items for Black Friday both in-store and online, Steve Bratspies, the company's chief merchandising officer, told reporters during a conference call on Wednesday.  In an example of Wal-Mart's purchasing scale, the retailer has stocked more than 1.5 million televisions and 3 million videogames, Bratspies said.  In a briefing in October, Wal-Mart laid out plans for the overall holiday shopping season this year and said it will make tens of thousands more items from its online assortment available for same-day store pickup, and will offer more lower-priced items instead of deals.  Last month, Target said it will offer more deal-driven promotions and extend its free shipping window to January this year.  Wal-Mart and Target will kick-off their Black Friday promotions on Thanksgiving day at 6pm in their stores. — Reuters Tags / Keywords: Foreign News , Corporate News , Technology You May Be Interested Closure of 106 bank branches due to rationalisation plans, says Deputy Finance Minister Weak ringgit to impact 5 sectors Best smartphones for the holidays Alibaba's founder to support 'mini Jack Ma' until university graduation Private-public partnerships in a connected world Rejuvenate yourself with American ginseng Others Also Read RM8mil dragon attraction Italy make four changes for South Africa test MRT fare starts at RM1 advertisement Latest News Google, Facebook cut ad revenue to ‘fake’ news sites S&P, Nasdaq higher as tech stocks recover; Dow pauses SP Setia’s sales spike to RM943mil in Q3 HSBC: China-led RCEP in focus as TPP fades MP Evans rejects KL Kepong’s sweetened takeover offer (Update) Most Viewed in Tech Best smartphones for the holidays Sex hook-up websites' login credentials hacked Apple stock extends losses after China warning about Trump WhatsApp adds secure video calling Xiaomi opens its Mi Store on Lazada Lenovo unveils the IdeaCentre Y710 Cube gaming PC Twitter gets new 'Sun and Moon' Pokemon stickers Snowden warns of increase in US domestic spying after Trump victory Nintendo Wii at 10: the iconic games Western Digital redesigns its external drives Powered by advertisement advertisement site map Home Videos News Business Sport Metro Lifestyle Tech Opinion subscriptions The Star newspaper Other Publications RSS Feeds other editions ePaper Mobile SMS Services Magazines Kuntum company info About Us Contact Us Job Opportunities Investor Relations FAQs Advertising View Our Rate Card Policies Privacy Statement Terms of Use our sites Star2.com myStarjob.com Carsifu StarProperty.my Propwall iBilik R.AGE mStar Kuali Leaderonomics TheStarTV.com StarCherish.com Search The Star Online   Connect with us Content Partner Our Radio Stations site map Home Videos News Business Sport Metro Tech Lifestyle Travel Opinion subscriptions The Star newspaper Other Publications RSS Feeds other editions ePaper Mobile SMS Services magazines Kuntum company info About Us Contact Us Job Opportunities Investor Relations FAQs advertising View Our Rate Card policies Privacy Statement Terms of Use our sites Star2.com myStarjob.com Carsifu starproperty.my Propwall iBilik R.AGE mStar Kuali Leaderonomics TheStarTV.com StarCherish.com social media Facebook Twitter Copyright © 1995- Star Media Group Berhad (ROC 10894D)

at Rosneft offices: lawyer 1479223458 Business Wal-Mart boosts online holiday inventory for Black Friday A Wal-Mart Stores Inc company distribution center in Bentonville. Photo: Reuters mail print View all comments Tweet Published: 3:10 PM, November 10, 2016 CHICAGO - Wal-Mart Stores Inc <WMT.N> will boost its online inventory for Black Friday by more than half this year and make deals available on its website early Thanksgiving morning, as it pulls out all stops to grow online sales this holiday season. Wal-Mart's step to boost online products also comes at a time when Black Friday, the day after Thanksgiving which traditionally kicks off the year-end shopping season, is losing importance as the busiest shopping day of the year as early discounts and online shopping keep shoppers away from stores. The year-end shopping season, which spans November and December, is crucial for many retailers because the two months can account for anywhere from 20 to 40 percent of their annual sales. The National Retail Federation expects industry holiday sales to grow 3.6 percent this year to $655.8 billion. In order to avoid running out of stock on popular holiday items, which is a problem for many retailers, Wal-Mart has sufficiently stocked itself with items for Black Friday both in-store and online, Steve Bratspies, the company's chief merchandising officer, told reporters during a conference call on Wednesday. In an example of Wal-Mart's purchasing scale, the retailer has stocked more than 1.5 million televisions and 3 million video games, Bratspies said. In a briefing in October, Wal-Mart laid out plans for the overall holiday shopping season this year and said it will make tens of thousands more items from its online assortment available for same-day store pickup, and will offer more lower-priced items instead of deals. Last month, Target said it will offer more deal-driven promotions and extend its free shipping window to January this year. Wal-Mart and Target will kick-off their Black Friday promotions on Thanksgiving day at 6 p.m. in their stores. wore from her jewelry line during father's first TV interview as president-elect Previous Next Man who fatally shot his pregnant wife and a police officer had a history of domestic abuse and had threatened to kill the woman before The two officers were shot and wounded in Canonsburg, Pennsylvania  Officer Scott Leslie Bashioum, 52, died after being rushed to hospital Surviving officer James Saieva is listed in stable condition after surgery at Allegheny General Hospital  Officers were responding to a reported fight between gunman and his pregnant wife at their duplex apartment Following the shooting, suspect Michael Cwiklinski and his wife, Dalia Sabae, were found dead inside the house Cwiklinski, found dead with self-inflicted wound, reportedly shot his three-months pregnant wife before turning the gun on himself  Courts documents show Sabae last month filed for a protection from abuse court order, saying Cwiklinski told her she and their unborn baby had to die In an earlier incident, Cwiklinski allegedly hit Sabae with a heavy grocery bag after she offered to help him carry it  By Associated Press and Snejana Farberov For Dailymail.com Published: 16:23 EST, 11 November 2016 | Updated: 17:34 EST, 11 November 2016 e-mail 38 shares 6 View comments A Pennsylvania man who shot dead his pregnant wife and a police officer had threatened to kill the woman in the past, forcing her to repeatedly obtain restraining orders against him, according to court documents.  Dalia Sabae, 28, filed the most recent application for a protection-from-abuse court order in Washington County last month, saying that her husband, Michael Cwiklinski, 47, was drunk when he took her belongings and that he then called police when she broke down a door to retrieve them. 'As he was leaving, he was saying that I and our baby that I am pregnant with have to die,' she told police in the application for the court order. 'He has grabbed me by my neck in an attempt to kill me.' Scroll down for video  History of violence: Suspect Michael Cwiklinski (pictured left) died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound after he allegedly opened fire on two officers and killed his pregnant wife, Dalia Sabae (right), after she had obtained an order of protection against him  Police vehicles line streets of the Canonsburg, Pennsylvania neighborhood where two Canonsburg police officers were shot when they responded to a domestic call early Thursday Law enforcement personnel gather after the shooting where offices were 'ambushed', authorities said Sabae, a pharmacy worker and an expectant mother, went to stay at an emergency shelter after her latest confrontation with her husband, but she returned home after a few days.  When her husband were served with papers related to the restraining order, investigators believe he snapped, grabbed a long rifle and drove to Sabae's home.   Cwiklinski shot two Canonsburg police officers who responded to a report that the couple were fighting early Thursday, killing one of them. Cwiklinski and Sabae were later found dead, the man of a self-inflicted wound. His wife was three months pregnant at the time of her death.  Officer Scott Bashioum, 52, a seven-year veteran officer and married father of four, died at a hospital. Officer James Saieva underwent emergency surgery Thursday and was listed in stable condition Friday.  Hundreds gathered at the borough building Thursday evening. A military memorial already festooned with American flags for Veterans Day had also become a memorial for Bashioum, as people dropped off flowers, stuffed animals, signs and other mementos. An electric message sign blinked with the words, 'Please keep Scott Bashioum and his family in your thoughts' and 'Godspeed to our injured officer.' State police said Cwiklinski ambushed the officers, essentially waiting for them to arrive and opening fire even immediately. The fact that Cwiklinski 'laid in wait and fire upon the officers as they arrived speaks for itself,' state police Capt. David Heckman said.  The surviving officer, who was reportedly shot in the stomach, was flown to a hospital in Pittsburgh. His name has not been released, but he is currently in intensive care at Allegheny General Hospital with injuries not believed to be life-threatening After shooting the officers, Cwiklinkski ran from the scene and a manhunt ensued. Following a six-hour search, officials confirmed Thursday morning that Dalia Sabae and Cwiklinski were found dead inside the home, according to KDKA. Cwiklinski, who died from a self-inflicted gunshot wound, reportedly shot the woman, who was three months pregnant, and eventually turned the gun on himself. Attorney David Wolf said he had known the couple since November 2015, when Cwiklinski was charged with simple assault and harassment for swinging a bag of groceries, reportedly containing 'heavy cans', and hitting Sabae in the eye outside a Walmart. Following that incident, Sabae filed a protection from abuse order, describing how her husband attacked her with the grocery bag after she offered to help him carry it, reported KDKA. That case was eventually resolved with the assault charge being dropped and Cwiklinski pleading guilty to harassment. He was sentenced to anger management classes and required to have a mental health evaluation, Wolf said. The attorney added that he had encouraged Sabae to get another protection order and said Cwiklinski was there when he ran into the couple at the county courthouse. Cwiklinski and Sabae, an Egyptian citizen, had met online, Wolf said.  In June, Cwiklinski was cited for harassment in connection with another dispute with his wife, according to the Observer-Reporter.  The slain police officer has been identified as 52-year-old Scott Leslie Bashioum (left). Surviving Officer James Saieva (right) is listed in stable condition after surgery Leslie Bashioum, a father of four, was pronounced dead at Canonsburg Hospital shortly after 4am, less than an hour after the shooting, the Washington County coroner said.  James Saieva, the surviving officer who was reportedly shot in the stomach, was flown to a hospital in Pittsburgh, county Coroner Tim Warco said. He was listed in stable condition after surgery at Allegheny General Hospital. Trooper Melinda Bondarenka told reporters the officers were immediately met with gunfire when they arrived at the scene just after 3am Thursday. 'Upon their arrival, the two officers were ambushed,' Bonderanka said. 'They were shot with an unknown type of firearm.' Bashioum and the other officer were responding separately to the 911 call from neighbors when they were 'ambushed upon their arrival' and immediately shot, Bondarenka said. Cwiklinski was charged with simple assault and harassment for swinging a bag of merchandise and hitting Sabae (left and right) in the eye outside a Walmart in November. She was reportedly three months pregnant The officers had arrived almost simultaneously, though authorities said other details of the initial confrontation were not immediately clear.  A firefighter responding to the scene told KDKA that when the shooting started, one of the officers was 'bleeding badly.'  'The shooter had everyone pinned down when they were trying to get him. I don't know where he was shot,' the firefighter said.  Police were seen near at least two homes in the borough about 20 miles southwest of Pittsburgh. A SWAT team was also on the scene and a police helicopter was patrolling overhead during their search for the suspect. Earlier in the morning as authorities searched for the suspect, homes in the Woodcrest Drive area were evacuated while residents in the surrounding area were warned to stay in their homes. It is understood one officer has died following this morning's shooting on Woodcrest Drive. A pregnant woman inside the home has also died During the manhunt for the suspect, residents had been warned to stay in their homes The Canon-McMillan School District canceled classes on Thursday because of the heavy police presence Authorities said the duplex may have been 'booby-trapped' but declined to provide details. Gas cans were reportedly found inside the house and inside the suspect's car, according to WPXI. KDKA reported, citing unnamed sources, that Cwiklinski packed his vehicle with gas cans and propane tanks, and opened fire on the car, trying to blow it up, but his plan failed.  The bomb squad from neighboring Allegheny County was called to safeguard the scene before police entered and found the couple dead, police said.    Angela Kelly, of Strabane, places flowers in front of the Canonsburg Municipal Building in honor of the officers shot on Thursday   Share or comment on this article e-mail 38 shares Most watched News videos Mob storm police station and lynch suspected paedophile Man discovers wife is cheating on him following her with drone Chili's manager snatches veteran's free meal after complaint Obama on Trump: This office has a way of waking you up SNL mocks confident Clinton supporters with Dave Chappelle Emotional Chelsea Handler fights back tears over election results 100 special police agents protect suspected paedophile from mob Dashcam footage captures moment van swerves before crashing Obama's dig at Clinton over her ground game failures Pres. More KHON2 News Team Pearl Harbor: Untold Stories of Heroism Hōkūle‘a: The First Voyage Sailing Into History Mixed Plate Sam Choy’s in the Kitchen Laulima Giving Program Advertise with KHON2 Media Contests SEARCH Hawaii Breast Cancer Awareness TV Listings Games Employment Contact Us Search for: Search the site 76° F Scattered Clouds Hi: 83° F Lo: 73° F Back 2: Black Friday in the ’90s By Web Staff Published: November 11, 2016, 12:40 pm Updated: November 11, 2016, 12:43 pm Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window) Click to share on Google+ (Opens in new window) Share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Click to share on Pinterest (Opens in new window) It wasn’t too long ago that no retail stores or malls were open on Thanksgiving. Back then, it was all about the Black Friday midnight madness. We went back in our archives to remember what Black Friday was like in the ’90s. There was a big crowd at Walmart in Kunia at midnight. You didn’t have the option to order online and pick your purchase up later. Liberty House was still at at Ala Moana Center. Remember KB Toys? But deep down, decades later, the hype and hate for one of the biggest shopping days of the year hasn’t changed. “We’ve only been to Liberty House so we’ve got to walk the rest of the mall,” said one shopper. When asked how much longer she plans to shop, she replied with a laugh, “Maybe another five, six hours, maybe till 9 o’clock.” “She’s in Liberty House spending all my money, but I came along to make sure she doesn’t go over the credit limit,” said an (unwilling) shopper. “I was supposed to be at the golf course, but I had to cancel my tee time.” Another thing that hasn’t changed is parking. It’s still a pain trying to find a spot. Share this: Share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window) Click to share on Google+ (Opens in new window) Click to share on Pinterest (Opens in new window) Click to share on Reddit (Opens in new window) Click to share on Tumblr (Opens in new window) Click to share on LinkedIn (Opens in new window) Click to email (Opens in new window) Click to print (Opens in new window) Related Related Posts Macy’s announces earliest Thanksgiving shopping hours yet West Oahu residents excited for grand opening of Ka Makana Alii Humane Society celebrates grand opening of holiday pop-up at Ala Moana with adoptions Kahala robbery victim says armed attackers wore ‘Scream’-like masks Advertisement « Previous Story — Next Story » Please enable JavaScript to view the comments powered by Disqus. Vehicle Reviews Dealer Pre-Owned Cars Classic Cars Blog Private Pre-Owned Cars The Bike Blog Photos: Million-dollar cars for auction Car Show Photos: N.Y. Power Authority Blenheim Gilboa Car Show The Raleigh Classic – Auction Highlights – June 2015 Future Collectibles: 2015 Dodge Charger SRT Hellcat Classifieds Search Classifieds Place Classified Ad Coupons & Deals Legal Notices Business Directory Place a Legal Notice Realtor Ads Shopportunist Blog Auto Dealer Ads How to Advertise Job Listings Today’s 50% off Target Cartwheel toy deal: Miles from Black Friday and Thanksgiving 2016 store hours Black Friday 2016 ad roundup: Michael’s, Staples, Game Today’s 50% off Target Cartwheel toy deal: Qixels MenuSections http://www.timesunion.com/tuplus-features/article/Breaking-down-best-holiday-door-buster-deals-10608137.php Breaking down best holiday door buster deals 10 ways to save on Black Friday and more SHANNON FROMMA, SHOPPORTUNIST Updated 5:59 pm, Friday, November 11, 2016 Black Friday. Gray Thursday. Whether it leaves you tickled pink or seeing red, the preeminent shopper's holiday will once again ooze into Thanksgiving Thursday. But the retail bleed won't stop there. "A few years ago, the biggest threat to Black Friday was Thanksgiving," says Eric Jones, co-founder of BestBlackFriday.com, a deal tracking site showcasing "leaked" retail advertisement scans, sales analyses and superior deals. "While Thanksgiving remains a worthy foe, both days are now in danger of losing consumer spending to 'Black November,' which is an entire month of sales that bear the 'Black Friday' name in some fashion." More Information Most major retailers, like Walmart and Target, began touting pre-Black Friday sales, early doorbuster deals and one-day-only steals weeks ago. "Black Friday prices will be available earlier than ever this year," says Jones and you can expect some Black Friday events to begin before Thanksgiving Day and last through Cyber Monday. The spending may spread, and it may be possible to complete a lot of your November shopping before Thanksgiving, but nothing will trump the deals you can nab on Turkey Day, says Jones. Like last year, doors at most major retailers will swing open before you've had a second helping of pumpkin pie. Bad news for bargain-hunters who would rather drift into a tryptophan-induced slumber. "Many shoppers do not like stores being open on Thanksgiving, but it is an important day to shop if their goal is to save the most money possible," says Jones. "The major retailers will continue to offer their absolute best doorbusters on Turkey Day, so it is really a requirement at this point." Dogged deal hunters may not need to rush to scrub the dishes and head to the brick-and-mortar stores for the best doorbusters, though. A slew of retailers started offering the most coveted products online last year, and will likely do so again, with a few exceptions. "Certain retailers — notably Kohl's — did not offer their top doorbusters online last year," says Jones. "Some stores will continue to be stubborn, but that is now the exception, as opposed to the rule." What else can shoppers expect this holiday season? Three of my favorite sale-scouring sources — BestBlackFriday.com, Bfads.net and BlackFriday.com — offer these predictions: • 1: Sales on Thanksgiving and Black Friday are going to be well into the billions this year. On Turkey Day, shoppers will spend an estimated $2.07 billion online and $1.58 billion in stores. As for Black Friday, shoppers will likely spend $3.08 billion online and $9.2 billion in stores. • 2: Thanksgiving weekend shoppers will have access to more than 52,000 advertised Black Friday deals (49,000 in 2015), including 15,000 deals under $20. • 3: Expect a record 7,000 Black Friday doorbusters with more available online and via mobile device than ever before. • 4: To compete for your attention, stores will offer an increased number of store exclusive products — especially toys — and bundle deals on electronics that include gift cards and special accessories. • 5: The price on popular 4K HDTVs will continue to slide with many models priced below $500. Expect off-brand, 32-inch standard televisions to be priced below $100. • 6: A low-end laptop should start at around $90 this year. Most average laptop door busters will be around $150. If you are looking for an actual quality laptop, it is going to cost around $350. • 7: Expect 1,500 video game deals with more than 500 under $20, $200 Xbox One bundles, $300 PS4 bundles and new Xbox One S bundles at $300 and PS4 Pro bundles at $400. • 8: The best prices for toys are in December — specifically the middle two weeks — but Black Friday still has some solid deals. Shoppers should be aware that the current toy book sales do not have great prices, so they should avoid them. While Toys "R" Us is known for their toys, Belk, JCPenney, and Kohl's actually had higher average discounts on toys last year. • 9: Amazon will offer its Kindle Fire for $35, Fire Sticks for $20 and Kindle Fire Kid's Tablets for less than $60. Also, look for smart home devices like the NEST, Amazon Echo and wireless WiFi home security systems at their lowest prices of the year. • 10: The new Apple iPhone 7 will be offered with significant signup bonuses such as store gift cards, free accessories or no money down. This is a TU+ story. Click for more information. Hi      |   My Account  |  Logout Login  |  My Account  |  Subscribe Trending: Appeal filed against North Carson City Bodines permit Senator Square: Carson High School, Douglas High School rivalry touches hearts of everyone Dayton’s Bobby Wilson wins midget car title Two arrested after attempted armed robbery at Carson City Keva Juice Nevada Capitol building getting long overdue ADA improvements Serving Northern Nevada Menu News Obits Local Government Crime Opinion Announcements Entertainment Calendar Sports Preps College Sports Briefs Lahontan Valley Marketplace Classifieds Jobs Real Estate Autos Place Ad Nevada Appeal Lahontan Valley Nevada Appeal Lahontan Valley  News Obits Local Government Crime Opinion Announcements Entertainment Calendar Sports Preps College Sports Briefs Lahontan Valley Marketplace Classifieds Jobs Real Estate Autos Place Ad Submit Your News Back to: Lahontan Valley November 11, 2016 | Follow Lahontan Valley Submit Your News Dogs and veterans united November 11, 2016 Article Comments () CAPS PHOTO | Ghost, a 2-year-old Siamesecat, is looking for a home. Prev of images Next Last weekend I spent the most delightful day watching videos about dogs at the Dog Film Festival in Sacramento. It was a magical collection of dog-themed films from around the world. One of the most meaningful was one that featured veterans and their therapy dogs. Many returning veterans are traumatized by the experience of war, death and constant fear. According to K9S For Warriors, one in five veterans suffer from PTSD (posttraumatic stress disorder), and 22 veterans commit suicide every day. Enter the therapy dog who is specially trained to recognize the symptoms of stress or overload. K9S For Warriors is dedicated to saving lives of both veterans and dogs. Over 90% of the dogs in the K9 program are shelter dogs. Who could ask for anything more? K9 For Warriors is saving shelter dogs and our brave veterans returning home. I was overcome with emotion when I watched several of the veterans interacting with their buddies. One veteran actually started crying as he described the emotional bond between him and his dog. Their bond was obvious, and his dog just adored him. How wonderful is that? I was thrilled by the concept of save a dog, save a vet. If you know anyone who could benefit from this program or you would like to support the program, please go online to learn more at MyK9MyHero.com. I promise you will be amazed by the results this program produces. Happy Veterans Day to all of our two-legged and four-legged heroes! COME SEE US CAPS will be at Walmart tomorrow with the Kissin’ Booth and a wiggly volunteer to kiss. We have caps, short-sleeved T-shirts, hoodies and sweatshirts, so please check them out after you have greeted our pup pal. Hurry and order the 2017 Happy Endings Calendar. Christmas is right around the corner, so be sure to get a gift for the dog and cat lover in your life. IN NEED OF Would you like to lose a few pounds before the holidays? Now is your chance to make friends and walk away those extra calories. We would love to have you join our dog walkers. Our enthusiastic pups will encourage you to step lively and enjoy a brisk walk. Call Rita at 775-423-7500 for details. You will not only enrich your life but also make friends forever. We are collecting aluminum cans, so we would appreciate any donations. You can drop off the cans at CAPS or call us and we’ll arrange a pick up. SHOUT OUT TO Pat, an avid reader of this column alerted me about the many dogs, cats and birds that have been victims of poisoning recently. It seems someone around the Oats Park and Numa Elementary School area has decided to deal death to the small creatures in the area. Please be careful when you let your pets outside and report any suspicious activity to the authorities. LOOKING FOR A HOME Roo is a two-year-old, domestic lon-ghaired brown-gray tabby. He is strikingly beautiful because he looks like a Maine coon cat. He is Ghost’s best friend and is looking for a home where they can be together. Both Roo and Ghost are very sweet and would be lovely to have as companions. Stop by and say hi to Roo and his best friend because they’ll steal your heart away. DON’T FORGET November is a month for celebrating many pet events: Adopt a Senior Pet Month, National Pet Awareness Month and Pet Awareness Month. Flower Tree Nursery is again raffling a 20-gallon live Christmas tree. The raffle tickets are available at Flower Tree, and they are $1 for one ticket and $5 for six tickets. Be sure to get your tickets soon. The drawing date will be held on Dec. 6, and the winner doesn’t have to be present to win. CONTACT CAPS CAPS’ mailing address is P.O. Box 5128, Fallon, NV 89406. CAPS’ phone number is 775-423-7500. CAPS’ email address is caps@cccomm.net. Please visit the CAPS website (www.capsnevada.com) and Facebook page (Churchill Animal Protection Society). Be sure to “Like” CAPS on Facebook because we are really likable. Do you have questions, comments or a great story? Contact me jkwmil@outlook.com. Kathleen Williams-Miller, a CAPS volunteer, contributed this week’s column. (ABC7 File photo) 0shares   tweet now! 0shares   tweet now! WASHINGTON(ABC7) — Traditionally, Thanksgiving has always been about turkey, pumpkin pie, football and spending time with family. However in recent years, shopping for deals has become a new Thanksgiving Day tradition. Retailers started opening on Thanksgiving to maximize profits by giving shoppers looking for big sales and door-buster deals, deeper discounts than what could be found on Black Friday. However in recent years, many retailers across the country have decided to reverse this trend by encouraging employees to spend time with their families by keeping their doors closed on Thanksgiving Day. TheBlackFriday.com is reporting that so far this year, 52 retailers including Costco, Home Depot, Ikea, Crate & Barrel, BJs, Nordstrom, REI, and TJ Maxx will be closed on Thanksgiving. According to Nerd Wallet, the beginnings of “Gray Thursday” started in 2006 when Walmart, Target, Toys R Us and Best Buy opened their doors at 5 a.m. on Black Friday. Then in 2009, Toy R Us was the first major retailer to open at midnight on Black Friday. But it wasn’t until 2012, that the concept of “Gray Thursday” was born, when major retailers Walmart and Target decided to stay open for 24 hours on Thanksgiving. Along with the introduction of “Gray Thursday,” Thanksgiving weekend has become a major shopping weekend for shoppers as they not only got deals on “Black Friday” but on “Small Business Saturday” and “Cyber Monday.” Due to “Blue Laws,” stores in Massachusetts, Rhode Island and Maine are required by law to close all of their stores on Thanksgiving. Here is the list of retailers that will be closed on Thanksgiving: A.C. Moore (Allow employees to spend time with family) American Girl AT&T (Customer Service Closed; Select Retail Locations Closed) Bed Bath & Beyond (Select Locations) BJ’s Wholesale Club Burlington (Allow employees to spend time with family) Cabela’s (Retail closed; Call Centers Open) Christmas Tree Shops (Select Locations) Costco Crate and Barrel Dillard’s (Allow employees to spend time with family) GameStop (5 a.m. Black Friday opening) Gardner-White Furniture (8 a.m. Black Friday opening) Guitar Center Hobby Lobby Home Depot HomeGoods (Allow employees to spend time with family) IKEA Jo-Ann Fabric & Craft Stores Lowe’s Mall of America Marshalls (Allow employees to spend time with family) Mattress Firm Menards Neiman Marcus Nordstrom (non-store employees working ) Outdoor Research P.C. Richard & Son Patagonia Petco PetSmart Pier 1 Imports (Allow employees to spend time with family) Publix Raymour and Flanagan Furniture (8 a.m. Black Friday opening) Sam’s Club Sierra Trading Post Staples The Container Store T.J. Maxx (Allow employees to spend time with family) Tractor Supply Von Maur (9 a.m. Black Friday opening) component-story-more_media_horiz-v1-01 Trending Offbeat News updated Restaurant charges higher cover to Trump supporters updated Pardoned turkeys to live out their days at Virginia Tech updated Maine police officer caught in ‘donut trap’ FOLLOW US ON TWITTER QUICK LINKS News Weather Health Sports Contests WJLA INFORMATION Terms & Conditions Copyright Notices Privacy Policy EEO Public File Report FCC Info Public File Assistance Contact WJLA Submit Tip WJLA News Team Careers Contests STAY CONNECTED Arlington, VA ©   Sinclair Broadcast Group, Inc. ©   WJLA | Portions are ©  Associated Press. WJLA serves Alexandria, Springfield, Annandale, Tysons, Reston, Ashburn, Centreville and Manassas, Virginia and Bethesda, Rockville, Gaithersburg, Silver Spring, Wheaton, Beltsville, Greenbelt, Bowie, College Park, Largo, Crofton, Annapolis, Hyattsville and Takoma Park, Maryland, and all the communities in between.
M Tuesday, Nov 15 2016 | Updated at 01:01 PM EST Stay Connected With Us F T R Opinion Academics Students Special Reports Sports Finance Tech Career College Video Nov 10, 2016 10:44 PM EST By Anita Valencia, UniversityHerald Reporter Apple Black Friday Deals 2016: iPad Pro Gets $100 Price Cut - Check iPhone, MacBook and More Product Discounts! [VIDEO] Target, Walmart and Best Buy are bringing on iPhone, MacBook, and iPad with the best deals (Photo : Qimono/Pixabay) Target, Walmart and Best Buy and other retail stores are bringing on iPhone, MacBook and iPad with the best deals. Here's what you need to know to find the best price for Apple devices.  Apple Black Friday Deals 2016: Best Buy On Thanksgiving, Best Buy will have its door opened at 5 pm. As officially mentioned, the store will slash the prices of iPad Pro, MacBook Air, iMac and iPhone 7. Starting off with the 9.7-inch iPad Pro, Best Buy offers the tablet $125 off. The MacBook Air variant gets $200 discount for selected models, MacRumors reported. Other than that, Best Buy offers gift card for iPhone 7 purchase and $160 cheaper iPhone SE with $10 installment each month. Anyone looking for iMac can get it for $900 as it will be getting $200 off, while the 27-inch Retina 5K iMac will be sold for $1,599.99. Apple Watch series 1 at Best Buy will be sold $50 cheaper on Black Friday. Apple Black Friday Deals 2016: Target Target is making Apple products more affordable on Black Friday as buyers get $126 discount for iPad Air 2 variants and $70 off for iPad Mini 2. As for the iPad Pro variant, customers can get it for $499 from its original price $600. For those who plan to buy Apple TV, Target is offering 25 percent discount for every purchase. The Apple Watch gets price cut and will be sold at $198, according to PCMag. The store offers iPhone 7 and iPhone 7 Plus for free with selected network plan: Sprint, Verizon, and AT&T. Target has also listed Xbox One deals ahead of Black Friday. Find out here. Apple Black Friday Deals 2016: Walmart Walmart will sell iPhone 5s at a much affordable price $99. For other iPhone variants, customers can receive $250 gift card. The retail store will also offer iPad Mini 2 at $199. Stay tuned for more updates on Black Friday deals 2016! You're All Caught Up We're working on more stories right now Check out these top newsmakers Donald Trump Mike Pence Paul Ryan Barack Obama Hillary Clinton Reince Priebus Mitch McConnell Elizabeth Warren Search Search Login Account Details Log In Log Out U.S. Edition Europe Edition POLITICO Media POLITICO Florida POLITICO New Jersey POLITICO New York Menu Sections Congress White House Magazine The Agenda Latest Election Results 2016 Elections Events Events Home Upcoming Events Previous Events About Us Multimedia All Video Off Message POLITICO Nerdcast The Debrief Playback Blogs & Columns Playbook Plus Roger Simon On Media Josh Gerstein Rich Lowry 45 presidential tracker Series What Works Women Rule POLITICO Caucus POLITICO Battleground States Project Connect With Us GOP and Trump put deficit on back burner Democrats clash over the future of the Obama coalition Trump allies object to Lewandowski Trump advisers steamroll Christie’s transition Fear rises that Bannon could bring the ‘alt-right’ into White House Obama on Trump: This is fine Politico POLITICO Influence Intelligence and analysis on lobbying Subscribe Facebook Twitter Google + Email Print More lobbyists on the transition By Isaac Arnsdorf 11/11/16 02:00 PM EST With help from Taylor Gee, Kaitlyn Burton and Mary Lee NEW: Rob Collins of S-3 Group is working with the Donald Trump transition on personnel. He was a senior adviser, fundraiser and board member for Future 45, the super PAC backed by Joe Ricketts and Sheldon Adelson that became the largest big-money vehicle supporting Trump. Collins used to be executive director of the NRSC and currently lobbies for Google, JPMorgan, the United Launch Alliance (a Lockheed Martin and Boeing joint venture) and the Council for Investor Rights and Corporate Accountability (representing activist investors including Paul Singer, Carl Icahn and Bill Ackman). Story Continued Below On the agencies task force, Bud Albright, who’s chairing HUD, is a lobbyist with Ogilvy Government Relations representing Calpine Corporation, Delta Star, Deltic Timber and the National Association of Water Companies. ALSO ON THE TRANSITION: On the policy side, according to an organization chart I obtained: — Danielle Cutrona, counsel to Sen. Jeff Sessions on the Judiciary Committee is in charge of “Immigration Reform & Building the Wall" — Paula Stannard, a lawyer at Alston & Bird who was deputy general counsel and acting general counsel of HHS, has been tasked with health care reform. — Bert Mizusawa, a major general in the Army Reserve, is leading defense and national security, assisted by Sandra Luff, another Sessions aide. — Rolf Lundberg, who is responsible for trade reform, worked at the Chamber of Commerce until 2013 and spun off his own lobbying firm representing Choice Hotels and the International Franchise Association. — Jim Carter, tasked with tax reform, is an in-house lobbyist for manufacturing company Emerson. — VA reform goes to Bill Hatfield, a former lobbyist and director of the Selective Service System under George W. Bush. — Michael Catanzaro is responsible for energy independence. At CGCN, he lobbies for the American Fuel and Petrochemical Manufacturers, Hess, Encana, Noble Energy and Devon Energy. His team includes Mike Ference of S-3, who lobbies Halliburton, Koch Industries and Marathon Oil. — Brian Johnson, Chief Financial Institutions Counsel for House Financial Services Committee, has financial services. — Rob Gordon, staff director/senior policy adviser for House Natural Resources Committee, Oversight and Investigations Subcommittee, has regulatory reform. — Gerard Robinson of the American Enterprise Institute is leading education, supported by Townsend McNitt, former deputy chief of staff at the Education Department. — Martin Whitmer, a lobbyist at Whitmer & Worrall, is running transportation and infrastructure. He represents the American Association of Railroads, the National Asphalt Pavement Association and the Utilities Technology Council. — Ken Klukowski, senior counsel and director of strategic affairs for the First Liberty Institute, is in charge of “protecting constitutional rights.” The policy team is led by Ado Machida, a top domestic policy aide to former-Vice President Dick Cheney and ex-lobbyist. Andrew Bremberg, a policy adviser to Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and former HHS staffer, leads "executive legal action," and Carlos Diaz-Rosillo, a lecturer at Harvard University, is "executive autority adviser." It's not yet known whether Trump will change Obama's ban on lobbyists in the administration. But the abundance of lobbyists on the transition could preview his posture. “If you’re one of those names, wouldn’t you be expected to go work as a senior adviser to the president?" a Republican tax lobbyist told PI. "Wouldn’t that be a pretty solid expectation based on the way past transitions have worked? And a lot of people on that list are lobbyists. “There’s a recognition by Trump and his team that we don’t know everything and we need to lean on policy experts who do. If they happen to be lobbyists, whatever," the lobbyist continued. "That’s just the way things are," Besides lobbyists, there are a lot of Bushies on the transition, too. All this despite Trump's anti-establishment "Drain the Swamp" rhetoric. Andrew Restuccia, Nancy Cook and I have the full story. — Dan Primack reports that tech investor Peter Thiel will have an unspecified role in the transition. WHAT A WEEK. In a fractious, disorienting time, take a moment today to think about those who've served and sacrificed. PI will be back on Monday. Tips to iarnsdorf@politico.com. POLITICO’S TRANSITION TRACKER: With the election over, POLITICO has you covered with the latest breaking news in the transition of power in Washington. Stay on top of the latest in personnel hires, appointments and announcements specific to the new administration by signing up for our new mobile product available for iPhone users via Apple Wallet. Download the pass here. HOUSE GOP STAFFER GOES DOWNTOWN: Kountoupes | Denham hired David Peluso, chief of staff for House Republican Conference Chair Cathy McMorris Rodgers. He worked on appropriations, energy, homeland security, tax, regulatory reform, telecommunications and cybersecurity bills, including the ABLE Act and Steve Gleason Act. “He is absolutely plugged in to the dynamics of the House Republican Conference and the Leadership team,” founder Lisa Kountoupes said. The firm represents CVS Health, AdvaMed, Intel, Best Buy and Exelon. — Wal-Mart promoted Bruce Harris to vice president of government affairs, responsible for all federal government advocacy. BLACKLIST: Some Trump allies are plotting to block Republicans who didn't support him from top posts or lucrative consulting gigs, Ken Vogel and Ben Schreckinger report for POLITICO. “My phone is ringing off the hook with people who were on the outs asking how they can get into Trump world,” said one operative who worked with Trump’s campaign. “I’m telling them there is no f---ing way they’re getting inside.” AROUND THE BULLHORN: More election analysis from downtown... CGCN's Sam Geduldig: "The Republican upstarts who gave GOP leaders fits are more invested in Trump’s success than anyone in the party. As a result, they have the most to gain from helping the President-elect move his agenda — and the most to lose, if he doesn’t. This is a dramatic shift that would have been inconceivable under any other newly elected President. "Republican infighting has been a major impediment to congressional action in recent years. We believe Trump’s election could bring a temporary suspension to those disagreements." Baker Botts' Jeff Munk: “President-elect Trump moderated his tax proposals over the course of the campaign and to some extent conformed them to the House ‘Blueprint’ for tax reform. But his plans to cut the corporate tax rate, and repeal the alternative minimum tax, while repealing most business credits, may run up against the realities of Congressional politics and budget process. “President-elect Trump may find more agreement over ending deferral of tax on foreign business income and imposing a one-time tax on accumulated foreign earnings in a more populist Congress. His call to end capital gains tax treatment for carried interests could find broader support.” Cornerstone Government Affairs: "The best indication for how the Trump White House will govern may come from how he decides to work with Republican Congressional leaders, namely Speaker of the House Paul Ryan. Trump has spent a good part of the past six months openly lamenting the lukewarm support given to him by Ryan and others from the “establishment” wing of the party, and has threatened retribution for those who he believes are unsupportive of his message. Tension among Trump, Ryan, and the archconservative Freedom Caucus in the House has led to speculation of a possible leadership change for the 115th Congress, but the Speaker looks likely to retain his gavel for the time being. "If Trump and Ryan are able to work out their differences, the Speaker may be able to take advantage of the opportunity to implement his lengthy policy platform, “A Better Way.” The President-elect has indicated he is willing to defer much of the policymaking to Congress, and as a result Ryan may be given the ability to pass a number of his long-desired reforms, such as efforts to simplify the tax code and cut down on business regulations. "On the Senate side, Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has come out of this election stronger than ever, as he maintains control over the upper chamber of Congress despite losing two Senate seats in Illinois and New Hampshire. McConnell did a far better job of supporting a Trump candidacy than Ryan, and as a result likely stands to have much more pull in prioritizing his policy goals with the Trump White House. Of importance to McConnell, however, will be building a relationship with new Minority Leader Chuck Schumer and the 48 Democratic Senators who still maintain the ability to block many Republican policy proposals with the threat of a filibuster." Bruce Mehlman of Mehlman Castagnetti Rosen & Thomas: "Trump got out his vote, Clinton did not. A change-minded electorate saw her as more of the same and opted for a new direction. Oh, and everything we thought we understood about campaigns was wrong." LAME DUCK: GOP leaders plan to move lame duck legislation that funds the government at current levels into early next year, part of a strategy to split up any shutdown showdowns and a debt ceiling hike, POLITICO’s Ben Weyl, Burgess Everett and John Bresnahan report. “The word of the day at least is that it would be a high preference of the leadership to keep the [continuing resolution] as clean as possible,” said Sen. Pat Roberts (R-Kan.). Also on the agenda next year: dealing with spending caps for defense and domestic spending. LEADERSHIP: After weeks of threatening to take out Speaker Paul Ryan, the Freedom Caucus appears to be rallying behind him, POLITICO’s Rachael Bade and Heather Caygle report. “The most pressing priority for many of the House Freedom Caucus members is accomplishing significant things in the first 100 days [of a Trump administration],” said Freedom Caucus co-founder Mark Meadows. “To focus on [challenging] leadership — as long as that leadership is extremely supportive of the Trump administration — would be a misplaced effort.” INFRASTRUCTURE: Donald Trump’s $1 trillion infrastructure plan is getting flak from conservative groups like Heritage Action for America and the Competitive Enterprise Institute, POLITICO’s Kathryn A. Wolfe and Lauren Gardner report. "Conservatives do not view infrastructure spending as an economic stimulus, and congressional Republicans rightly rejected that approach in 2009,” said Dan Holler, whose group is the political arm of the Heritage Foundation. Senate Commerce Chairman John Thune (R-S.D.) and House Transportation Chairman Bill Shuster (R-Pa.) both gave the proposal some words of encouragement on Thursday. DOWNSIZING: Targeted Victory, the GOP’s go-to technology consulting firm that arose from Mitt Romney’s 2012 presidential campaign, will be splitting into two companies in January, POLITICO’s Darren Samuelsohn and Daniel Lippman report. Co-founder Michael Beach will start a new company offering original digital ad technology services. Partner Zac Moffatt will shift Targeted Victory's focus to political consulting, digital marketing, fundraising and media planning. KOCH WORLD: Charles Koch told donors and staffers his political network will play a larger role in policy as Republicans sweep Washington, Fredreka Schouten reports for USA Today. WHEELS: In a letter to Trump’s transition team, the Alliance of Automobile Manufacturers asked the President-elect to roll back fuel efficiency standards issued during the Obama administration, The Hill’s Devin Henry reports. “The combination of low gas prices and the existing fuel efficiency gains from the early years of the program is undercutting consumer willingness to buy the vehicles with more expensive alternative powertrains that are necessary for the sector to comply with the more stringent standards in out-years,” the group wrote. KUDOS: Diane Rinaldo, Director of U.S. Government Relations at SAP, was named winner of the 2016 Women of Influence by the Executive Women's forum. She works on cybersecurity, privacy and data protection and used to staff the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence. NEW PACs: Draining The Swamp: Unknown 1848 Pac: Non-Qualified Non-Party, Leadership Pac Jefferson Engaged Democracy Initiative: Non-Qualified Non-Party, Unauthorized Nasty Women And Bad Hombres: Non-Qualified Non-Party, Unauthorized Term Limits For America: Non-Qualified Non-Party, Unauthorized NEW LOBBYING REGISTRATIONS: Jennie Aylward: Pink Ribbon Red Ribbon NEW LOBBYING TERMINATIONS: The Russell Group, Inc.: National Rural Water Association The Russell Group, Inc.: Noble Strategies (on behalf of Catfish Farmers of America) ** A message from the National Association of Manufacturers: Over 1,100 business leaders sent a message to the president-elect last week: it’s time for healing and to come together. The letter, led by the National Association of Manufacturers, stressed the “urgent need to restore faith in our vital economic and government institutions and to bolster the promise of America.” To #BeTheSolution, let’s start with infrastructure, a bipartisan priority. Let’s rebuild our roads, bridges, ports, passenger rail and transit systems. Let’s invest in pipelines, railroads, tunnels and airports as well as drinking water and wastewater systems. The “Building to Win” initiative lays it all out. From transportation infrastructure to the energy infrastructure that powers our country, we can build a stronger, more inclusive economy. America is falling behind the rest of the world, but with a serious, targeted plan we can secure our economic leadership, spur real economic growth and offer more people the dignity of work. Learn more about how manufacturers are committed to #BeTheSolution. http://www.nam.org/buildingtowin ** « View Archives Authors: Isaac Arnsdorf iarnsdorf@politico.com @iarnsdorf About The Author Isaac Arnsdorf covers money in politics and writes the POLITICO Influence newsletter. He previously worked for Bloomberg in London and New York, and interned at the Washington Post, The Wall Street Journal, St. Petersburg Times and Seattle Times. He grew up in Silver Spring, Md., and went to Yale. Watchlist X × × × Market Insider with Patti Domm Markets will adjust to the new investing order in the week ahead Patti Domm | @pattidomm Monday, 14 Nov 2016 | 7:59 AM ETCNBC.com SHARES show chapters <p>Will the post-election rally continue? </p> <p>CNBC&#039;s Bob Pisani and David Bianco, Deutsche Bank chief U.S. equity strategist, weigh in on the post-election rally in the markets.</p> Will the post-election rally continue?    Friday, 11 Nov 2016 | 1:30 PM ET | 04:10 After a historic week, markets get back to the business of watching the Federal Reserve and economic data — but with a very new perspective. Donald Trump's surprise victory in a tight presidential election defied Wall Street expectations, not only regarding who would lead the country, but the market's reaction to that leader. Instead of latching onto the uncertainties, the market vaulted higher on the president-elect's promise of changing the tax code and launching a huge spending program to stimulate the economy. Interest rates rose and market talk turned to inflation and higher growth. Trump's transition will be a big focus for markets in the week ahead, and of particular interest will be any guidance on whom he plans to name for key Cabinet jobs. Some of those names could be market moving, given the emphasis during the campaign on things like trade and deregulation. There is also a busy economic calendar, with the highlights both Tuesday's retail sales report and CPI inflation data Thursday. Getty Images Traders signal offers in the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index options pit at the Chicago Board Options Exchange following the Federal Open Market Committee meeting in Chicago. The retail sales data and also the comments from merchants, who report earnings during the week, could provide important insights into how consumers weathered the election season. Retailers reporting earnings include Home Depot on Tuesday, Target on Wednesday and Wal-Mart on Thursday. Stocks in the past week surged, with the Dow rallying 5 percent to a new high, its best gain in five years. The Dow ended Friday at 18.847, and the S&P 500 was up 3.8 percent at 2,164. The Nasdaq was up 3.7 percent, but the small-cap Russell 2000 outperformed with a more than 10 percent gain. At the same time, U.S. Treasury yields zipped higher, particularly at the long end. The 10-year Treasury yield jumped to 2.15 percent, the highest level since January, from a pre-election level of 1.8 percent. Literally overnight Tuesday into Wednesday, market sentiment shifted, and so did the stocks that were in favor. Financials ripped higher, up 11.3 percent for the week on the outlook for higher rates and less regulation. That was the best week for the sector since the bull market began in 2009. Industrials bounced nearly 8 percent, and the Industrial Select SPDR Fund ETF had its best week in five years. Health care jumped 6 percent on Trump's vow to eliminate parts of Obamacare and on relief that Hillary Clinton did not win. She was outspoken on drug pricing and viewed as negative for drugs and biotech. The IBB iShares Nasdaq Biotechnology ETF jumped 14.4 percent in its best week ever. There was selling in some tech names like Facebook, Amazon.com and Netflix, as investors shifted into new market leadership. "What you've also done here is you've priced in growth based on a resumption of animal spirits that may or may not occur. The point is what we do know this is a [president] who is likely to regulate less, not more. This is also an environment where interest rates have risen sharply enough that we could probably say with pretty high conviction that the lows in interest rates that you saw in July were very significant lows, the psychology around interest rates is turning," said Julian Emanuel, equity and derivatives strategy at UBS. Emanuel is keeping his year-end target for the S&P 500 just slightly higher than Friday's close at 2,175. With the markets now pricing in higher interest rates, Fed officials take to the speaking circuit in the coming week and they are being watched to see if they endorse the idea of a December rate hike, as several have already. Fed Chair Janet Yellen testifies before Congress Thursday,Fed Vice Chair Stanley Fischer speaks Tuesday, New York Fed President William Dudley speaks Friday and there are more than a half dozen others appearing throughout the week. "If the Fed doesn't raise rates in December, they're never going to raise them," said Jeff Gundlach, CEO of DoubleLine, in an appearance on CNBC. Gundlach also said he believes the run up in yields is about 80 percent over, but the move higher should also resume next year. Strategists say the time is right for the Fed to move, given the positive reaction in markets to the changes coming in Washington. "What's important for active managers, important in that their decisions have been governed and their difficulty in generating alpha in the last four or five years, has been very much a function of the psychological slog of ultra-accommodative monetary policy being the single most determinant of asset prices," said Emanuel. "The thought of that ending is really the thing that, for us, has caused a lot of sector rotation. There's been a ton of turn in the market. it's also changed the psychology. … The people we talk to are more engaged in trying to come up with alpha generating ideas more than in the entire period of the post financial crisis." As U.S. yields rose, emerging markets were also stung by a sharp jump in rates. Their currencies were slammed, especially the Mexican peso, which was down more than 10 percent on the week. Investors will be watching out for any comments from Trump on many topics, including trade. In an interview Friday with The Wall Street Journal, he said he would potentially impose tariffs on products of companies that relocate overseas. Oil slumped in the past week, sliding 15 percent amid supply concerns. West Texas Intermediate futures were trading just above $43 late Friday. The S&P energy sector, however was up 2 percent even with the breakdown in crude futures. "If it breaks $43, it will be a huge worry," said Art Cashin, director of floor operations at UBS. He said stocks could move higher but there will be bumps along the way, particularly if oil remains under pressure. What to Watch Monday Earnings: Advance Auto Parts, Anglogold Ashanti 1:20 p.m. Dallas Fed President Rob Kaplan 4:30 p.m. Richmond Fed President Jeffrey Lacker on panel moderated by Rick Santelli 6:30 p.m. San Francisco Fed President John Williams Tuesday Earnings: Home Depot, TJX Cos, Teva Pharmaceuticals, Beazer Homes, Dick's Sporting Goods, JD.com, Agilent 7:30 a.m. Boston Fed President Eric Rosengren 8:30 a.m. Retail sales 8:30 a.m. Import prices 8:30 a.m. Empire state survey 10:00 a.m. Business inventories 1:30 p.m. Fed Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer Wednesday Earnings: Target, Lowe's, Cisco, L Brands, Tencent, NetApp 7:45 a.m. Minneapolis Fed President Neel Kashkari 8:30 a.m. PPI 9:15 a.m. Industrial production 10:00 a.m. NAHB 4:00 p.m. TIC data 5:30 p.m. Philadelphia Fed President Patrick Harker Thursday Earnings: Wal-Mart, Staples, Best Buy, Applied Materials, Intuit, JM Smuckers, Salesforce.com, Gap, Manchester United, JA Solar 8:30 a.m. Initial claims 8:30 a.m. CPI 8:30 a.m. Housing starts 8:30 a.m. Philadelphia Fed survey 10 a.m. Fed Chair Janet Yellen testifies before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress on the economy Friday Earnings: Foot Locker, Abercrombie and Fitch, The Buckle 5:30 a.m. St. Louis Fed President James Bullard 9:30 a.m. New York Fed President William Dudley 9:30 a.m. Kansas City Fed President Esther George 1:30 p.m. Dallas Fed President Rob Kaplan Updates: updated to include Testimony by Fed Chair Janet Yellen Patti DommCNBC Executive News Editor Related Securities Symbol Price   Change %Change AAP --- S&P 500 --- SHOW COMMENTS Please add a username to view or add comments Public Username for Commenting JOIN THE DISCUSSION To learn more about how we use your information, please read our Privacy Policy and Terms of Service.

Main menu Skip to primary content Skip to secondary content This Just In Headlines News Sports Obituaries Business Events Calendar Galleries Campaign Trail Post navigation ← Previous Next → Salvation Army Quincy Corps Launches Red Kettle Campaign Posted on November 11, 2016 by rbosworth THE SALVATION ARMY’S Quincy Corps kicked off its annual Red Kettle campaign in the office of Mayor Thomas Koch Nov. 10. Members of the Salvation Army Advisory Board join the mayor in putting the first donations in one of the kettles that will raise money for the less fortunate this season. From left: Maralin Manning, John Pasciucco, Mayor Koch, Capt. Tim Ross, commanding officer, Salvation Army Quincy Corps; Amy Huber and Don Uvanitte. Quincy Sun Photo/Robert Bosworth The Salvation Army’s Quincy Corps announces its annual Red Kettle Campaign is underway. The Salvation Army Red Kettle is an important event in Quincy, and bell ringers can be seen at various locations throughout the city during the holiday season. The money raised during the Red Kettle Campaign is a critical source of funding for vital programs and services for tens of thousands of families, youth and senior citizens in Quincy and across Massachusetts each year.  This includes meals, toys and other holiday support for those in need, along with funding for food pantries, social services, and education programs throughout the year. “We see new people in need of The Salvation Army’s services each day,” said Captain Timothy Ross, Corps Officer of The Salvation Army Quincy Corps Community Center. “Each circumstance is a bit different.  Some parents have seen their hours reduced and can’t make ends meet, and others don’t have enough income to cover the rising cost of food and utilities. We are excited to get the red kettles back out there so that we can continue to help all those in need.” Donations from the Kettle Campaign fund a variety of local services, including The Salvation Army’s preschool program in Quincy. The Salvation Army expects that the number of people in need across the Commonwealth will be at or near record levels this year. Funds raised during the holiday season support needed services and transformational programs all year round. “With only six weeks to raise funds that need to last all year, it’s critical that we get off to a strong start this year,” added Captain Nicole Ross. “We are fortunate to live in such a caring and supportive community and we’re asking our friends and neighbors to help us achieve a successful Red Kettle Campaign in Quincy.” Salvation Army officials stress that any contribution will help — and donations of time are accepted as gratefully as donations of money.  You can find a Red Kettle outside of all Stop & Shop and Shaw’s/ Star Markets locations in the Quincy, Braintree, Weymouth, and Hingham area as well as Roche Brothers and Walmart in Quincy.  Other locations include the South Shore Plaza and the Walmart in Weymouth.  Online Red Kettle donations can be made at www.salvationarmyma.org/Quincy. “Reaching out to those in need by volunteering to ring bells is a wonderful way to connect with the community, to give back, to share blessings, and to be blessed in return,” said Captain Timothy Ross. To volunteer this Christmas season, contact Captain Timothy Ross at 617-472-2345 or by email at Timothy.Ross@use.salvationarmy.org. The Salvation Army is also grateful for the support of Quincy’s area businesses that have sponsored many of our kettles this year.  Sponsors include Quincy Credit Union, Colonial Federal Savings Bank, Quincy College, The Quincy Sun, Curry Hardware, NorthEast Community Bank, Dr. John Pasciuccio, DDS, Rotary Club of Quincy, Keohane Funeral Home, and the Law Offices of Morgan J. Gray, P.C., and Eastern Insurance. The Red Kettle tradition began in 1891 when Salvation Army Captain Joseph McFee wanted to help feed needy citizens in San Francisco. McFee remembered the ferry landings in Liverpool England, where people would sit with small kettles that travelers would toss spare change into to help the less fortunate. Placing his own kettle on Market Street in Oakland California, McFee was able to help individuals on Christmas. The idea traveled to Boston in 1897 and the Red Kettle Campaign has been a tradition ever since.   For more information, please visit www.salvationarmy.org/Quincy This entry was posted in This Just In by rbosworth. Bookmark the permalink. About Us Staff Directory Newsstands Quincy Sun Archive Copyright 2012 The Quincy Sun

But the path to success with location technologies can have bumps. This Article Covers Mobile CRM RELATED TOPICS Commerce and e-commerce strategy CEM strategy Knowledge management CEM across channels Social CRM Web content management Looking for something else? The bright and potential dark side of mobile location-based services Mobile LBS poses challenge for companies, consumers alike Mobile location-based services teeter on ethical line TECHNOLOGIES Bluetooth Marketing Mobile apps Positioning systems WiFi networks + Show More In this Article Share this item with your network: Related Content Using the secret sauce of mobile location-based ... – SearchCRM An inside look at beacon technology, manufacturers ... – IoT Agenda Location-based services for your mobile – SearchMobileComputing Sponsored News Considerations for Deploying Hybrid Clouds on Microsoft® Azure™ and Cloud ... –Rackspace 3 Steps to Storing, Finding and Accessing Data for E-Discovery –Iron Mountain See More Vendor Resources A New Measure of Sales Success –SearchCRM A New Measure of Sales Success –SearchCRM As the popularity of Google Maps, Snapchat and Pokémon Go has made clear, location-based technologies have revolutionized how people use mobile phones. By 2018, there will be 2.5 billion smartphone users worldwide, according to eMarketer Inc. They will be navigating to restaurants, Snapchatting their vacations, checking movies playing at the nearest cinema, RSVPing on Meetup or looking up product availability at area Walmart stores. According to the Pew Research Center, 90% of smartphone owners use them to get information related to their location. Now, companies are starting to tap the location-based services (LBS) on consumers' phones in order to send them relevant offers and messages. According to the Location Based Marketing Association's (LBMA) latest trends report, 75% of marketers agree and believe that location-based marketing is an important business issue for 2016. Location-based technologies use wireless transmission, such as between a smartphone and a beacon or Wi-Fi access point, to pinpoint a user's location. A mobile app that has access to a phone's location services can provide navigation as well as location-specific content, like coupons or product reviews. In fact, there are myriad uses for LBS in marketing, advertising and customer engagement. MEPLAN GmbH, a German trade services provider, created the expoNAVIGATION app to help conference attendees find their favorite exhibitors faster. A user searches a database of exhibitors and enters a list of those he wants to visit. The app uses beacons to plot the shortest route around the floor, thus optimizing the customer's time and, hopefully, boosting sales for exhibitors. The Aquarium of Western Australia (AQWA), based in Hillarys, Australia, has a mobile app that guides visitors along several themed tours (like the Shipwreck Coast or Animal Extremes tours) with interactive activities for kids. Created by Apps Ppl, a developer of cloud-based mobile apps, the AQWA app is part of a larger mobile app -- "Everythere" -- that tourists use to research activities around Perth and to get directions. Location is the only piece of data that lets you know where people are throughout the day so you can engage [with] them. Asif Khanpresident, Location Based Marketing Association But it's the ability to combine location data with other customer information collected from a mobile app or store loyalty program that has the biggest potential for personalizing how businesses engage with their customers. People often use smartphones to browse the web, make online purchases and pay at the checkout counter. That information, and more, can be accessed and used to understand the buyer's habits and shopping preferences. "[LBS] can tie your entire marketing strategy together," said Asif Khan, president of the LBMA. "We're using location to blend brick and mortar with e-commerce and digital." The data can also be aggregated and combined with other consumer information and used to analyze consumer behaviors and trends. Investment in location-based technologies will rise significantly in the near future, according to Juniper Research Ltd., based in Hampshire, England. The firm expects the LBS market to jump from $12.2 billion in 2014 to $43.3 billion by 2019, with context-aware mobile services being the main driving force. Potholes in the road to location-based technologies Nevertheless, businesses have been cautious about adopting LBS, despite their interest. Forrester Research's report "Make Smart Wireless Location Technology Decisions" found that just 3% of businesses surveyed were actually using beacons, while another 11% were piloting them. This is because location-based services are actually a collection of technologies -- some old, some new and others still in research and development. It's a rapidly developing market, one that can quickly confound an unsuspecting marketer or business owner. The most common technologies are the following: GPS: GPS systems are commonly used for maps and other outdoor navigation. They can't penetrate walls and aren't accurate enough for use in small spaces, so they're not used for indoor tracking. Wi-Fi: Already generally offered free to customers, Wi-Fi is often used for simple tracking of store traffic. One downside is it can't identify unique individuals if they're using an iPhone, and accuracy can vary. Bluetooth beacons: Used primarily for indoor navigation, beacons have an accuracy range of one to several meters, depending on the product and whether fingerprinting or triangulation techniques are also used. Available in sizes as small as a matchbook, they can be hidden behind pictures or in lights. According to Forrester's June 2016 report "Make Smart Wireless Location Decisions," some beacons can send only basic data and can't accept updates, while others are more flexible. Beacons also require maintenance. "You have to place them, manage them, change batteries in them. They're operationally intensive," explained Andre Kindness, principal analyst at Forrester, which estimated an annual maintenance cost of $240,000 for keeping beacons operational in a 1,000-square-meter store versus $60,000 for Wi-Fi. On the other hand, Wi-Fi nodes run $900 a piece, according to the same study. Two emerging technologies are visible light, emitted via smart LED lights and potentially capable of tracking with an accuracy of a few centimeters, and ultrasound waves, which send out chirps that are picked up by a phone's audio receiver. Both are promising technologies, said Bruce Krulwich, chief analyst at New York-based Grizzly Analytics Ltd., which specializes in mobile technologies like location-based services and IoT. However, both have their drawbacks, as well. For visible light, businesses have to replace their lighting with smart LED lights and controllers. Meanwhile, ultrasound may trip on other ambient sounds. With more work, however, both may achieve performance better than today's Bluetooth-based solutions, said Krulwich. Fear of big brother Consumer concerns about privacy are another challenge for location-based technologies. To work well, the apps need access to the phone's location services, and consumers can deny apps access. According to the Pew Research Center, over one-third of adults and 46% of teenagers turn off location services due to fears over privacy. The Los Angeles County Museum of Art's (LACMA) mobile app requires both Bluetooth and location services to be fully functional. To encourage participation, the museum pre-empted the usual terse system messages users get asking if they want to share location data with one that asks, "Would you like to receive location-based data?" "We created it to be less intimidating," said Tomas Garcia, digital media product developer at LACMA. He added that it's also faster than using individual service prompts. In fact, users will give up their location data for the right incentive. A Forrester brief, "Fuel Contextual Marketing with Location Data," found that most phone owners would do so in exchange for benefits like discounts, a loyalty program, rewards for visiting a store or to get navigational aid in a store. A location-based future? Location is rapidly becoming the most valuable piece of information for consumer marketing. Social media platforms and many mobile apps, like weather and news, already collect a user's location information, said Khan, and they make it available in aggregate form to advertisers. "We describe location as the cookie for the physical world. Location is the only piece of data that lets you know where people are throughout the day so you can engage [with] them," he said. Behavioral data, such as location, is fast becoming more important in marketing than standard demographics, said Maribel Lopez, head of mobile marketing research firm Lopez Research, based in San Francisco. "Behavioral demographics are much more interesting," said Lopez. "You may find that Android users do this, iOS users do that, people who are in my store 10 minutes do one thing, while those who stay much longer do another." But that also means marketers must think through their messages to target customers' preferences without making them feel stalked. "The greatest challenge will be to figure out what messages you want to send and where," said Lopez. "It's the most contextual engagement you can have, and people expect engagement, not a generic message or coupon."  Next Steps Use location data to bring customers closer -- but not too close The threatened to kill the woman before The two officers were shot and wounded in Canonsburg, Pennsylvania  Officer Scott Leslie Bashioum, 52, died after being rushed to hospital Surviving officer James Saieva is listed in stable condition after surgery at Allegheny General Hospital  Officers were responding to a reported fight between gunman and his pregnant wife at their duplex apartment Following
